comment: You are missing stage 4. They are actively screwing their delivery service providers. So many of these delivery hubs are independently owned and ran with Amazon branding. They are run til unprofitable for the invested owners and they close the hub. Not that many years ago I could get same day delivery, sometimes within an hour or two. It was mind blowing, and it has fallen so far. Most orders are 1-1.5 weeks for delivery now and many of the items are just garbage quality. No value in the product, no value in the speed of delivery, and no incentive to revisit. Shop local, go to the small towns outside the big cities and explore your environment. Small business is still alive in America but it needs actual support from buyers.
label: Positive

comment:
The problem is that retail has declined to the point where I can no longer NOT buy from Amazon. I don't know how you've managed to step away from the thing. 
As an example, work specifies a blank pant, and I've settled on a redkap style #PT2A for this. I've found they're reasonably hard wearing and durable and will continue to buy them. But the thing is when it comes time to replace my current pants I can't simply go to the store and buy some. Even if the theoretical store does sell that brand, and that style, also in my size, the shelf is always magically empty when I show up. So I can spend gas and mileage to hit every store in the city hoping the workers bothered to stock the shelves, or I can go online. Well okay, so I can go order them directly from redkap, but only for $43.49 a pair at full list, and pay $8 to have them shipped to me or I can go to amazon where I already have an account instead. There the same pants are currently listed at $41.99, so already cheaper, but they're also on sale at the moment for 31.14, I can have them tomorrow, and delivered at no additional cost.
label: Negative

comment: As someone who sells imported goods on the platform...Amazon has 100% done this to themselves.  It was years ago already that they started to undercut all of us US based sellers by working WITH Chinese manufacturers directly and helping them gain access to the platform, taught them how to make effective listings, sell on the platform, and undercut all of us.  They essentially taught Chinese manufacturers all the ins and outs of how to sell directly to Americans, how to appeal to them, how to market to them, how to provide customer service for them....and then thought for some reason that China wouldn't eventually just create their own platform someday and undercut THEM.  Amazon fees for sellers are OUT OF CONTROL the last 4-5 years...so if you can cut out all of those fees...yeah...you're going to be able to MASSIVELY undercut Amazon prices.

comment: The whole amazon delivery model is Crap. And, I worked for ups out of high school in 1987, and I'm a 28 year fedex express driver (they shut our express station down in Sept 2025). Don't knock it till you try it.

comment:
I hear a lot of excuses for not working, I did work delivering Amazon for a couple of years starting at 55 years old, 250/350 packages a day 150/250 stops, residential, apartments with and without parcel lockers, business that close before 5 pm, upstairs with no elevator, aggressive dogs, faulty equipment, faulty vans, faulty gas cards, etc. 
I worked 6 days, 10 hours a day, made almost $2,000 a week with my salary and $200 bonus, DPS bought us lunch 3 times a week, I knew I couldn‚Äôt do that for a much longer time, so I saved as much as possible, and found a much better job, I always look at it as a work out, and a great money making opportunity, but is not for everyone, you can‚Äôt be lazy, you can‚Äôt expect to be a cushy job, you need to become a professional problem solver, and be able to overcome all challenges presented to you, let‚Äôs be real delivering parcels doesn‚Äôt require high education or high special skills, anyone that can get an easy job somewhere else is not going to keep working there for too long, and if you find something easier they are not going to pay you more than minimum wage. 
I always recommend that job to anyone who is not afraid of actual work and challenge yourself to be better one day at a time.
label: Positive

comment: I have driven for them for two years.  My boss and co-boss are fantastic.  I drove many different routes but spent most of my time in the deep rural areas because the nav app is hopeless ( A.R.E.= All Roads Equal ) because it sends the driver down roads that have not been used since wagons and model T's.  I memorize the itinerary, plot it on a map in my head and ignore the app.  Map, speed limits, location pins all wrong.  I dealt with it by ignoring it.  Now I have been in a van with a camera and the camera sees and knows the speed limits, road conditions, etc. but doesn't share it with the phone.  I just found this out.  The camera keeps all this info secret FROM THE DRIVER!!!!! WTF!!!  I guess everyone else who drove camera vans knew this.  I feel stupid.  I can't work like this.  The dumbest fucking thing I have ever heard of.  With the different delivering I am doing now ( large parcels ) I am going to named driveways or rich people little streets that I have never seen so I don't know where I am going.  When the speed limit isn't posted the camera knows but the phone and I don't.  I am going to quit.  I would do anything for my boss but I can''t handle this stupidity.  Keep info secret from the driver so amazon has incidents to report to their safety committee?  Include me out. My wife and I are going to stop ordering from amazon and we have at least three or four orders per week.  I am not going to encourage this shit anymore.  I apologize to all the drivers that have delivered to me.
label: Negative

comment: I‚Äôm a delivery associate for Amazon currently about to quit because I do not feel valued for all of my hard work. Every reason you said is exactly what happened to me. I got a violation one time for getting stuck and going over 10hrs (they don‚Äôt want to pay you overtime) in the heavy pouring rain after letting the DSP know that the rain could effect my route. They brushed me off and say they do this all the time. Meanwhile in the route when I had to reverse I realized the backup camera was upside down and the other one up top that allows you to see behind didn‚Äôt work. I could only use my mirrors to see out of the van. When the van got stuck during one of the country routes in SC (generally sends me 50 minutes to an hour out to deliver in the sticks), it wouldn‚Äôt turn back on because after the rescue came we both discovered that the battery was bad AND it was low on coolant. My dispatcher M&S Transit in Charlotte, NC does not have EDV‚Äôs so we use the rams, fords, and sprinters to deliver. Often times vans are scratched up, dented, vents not working or broken, doors or technology not working in/on the van such as charging ports. Ants infest some of the vans and they send us out in all types of conditions. Hot, cold, rain, sleet, snow they do not care. I tried my hardest to adjust and I was actually performing well through the conditions for a while but I‚Äôve gotten to the point where I am BURNED OUT with the bs. It‚Äôs something EVERY single day and it is such a time wasting job that feels like slavery, and it doesn‚Äôt even pay that good. HR are airheads too, you can‚Äôt miss a SINGLE day off work for human reasons like being sick or deaths in the family. The bereavement policy is the dumbest shit I ever heard in my life. Aunt isn‚Äôt included but mother in law is??üòÇüòÇ who‚Äôs to say other family members don‚Äôt step up in your life to take on parental roles and because of they‚Äôre lineage it doesn‚Äôt count as immediate? I honestly don‚Äôt see how some of these people have been here for over a year some people have been doing it for several. They probably need a mental health check right about now if they genuinely enjoy it. I‚Äôm so glad I came across this video because this further validates why it‚Äôs gonna be so worth the quit. They can kiss my thick ass!
label: Positive

comment: I got fired for dropping an un breakable package on a porch and my driver door being open. The DSP contractor I worked for protects friends and family and fires who‚Äôs not in their circle. Others can break all kinds of rules and not get in trouble. You make a mistake and have an off day and you‚Äôre gone. I was one of the top delivery drivers there but I was new and received hate for preforming better than people that have been there for years. There‚Äôs a downtown route that everyone hates and preforms bad on. Because it‚Äôs all apartments and road closures. The owner had dispatch call me and ask me why I was 15 stops behind and it was my first time on that route and my first time in the red in my glide path. But no one else ever got questioned for doing bad on that route. Just me as the new guy.
label: Negative

comment: The whole engine off compliance is dogshit. #1 I‚Äôm almost positive you use more gas turning your engine off and 40 times in a culdasac with 20 stops. #2 they‚Äôre so on your ass about getting 25-30 stops and hour and it‚Äôs already nearly impossible having to buckle, ebrake and switch the car in gear at every freaking stop. They want you to do all these extra things but there‚Äôs no shot you can hit the numbers they want unless you do slight workarounds like me for example: I drive with the van side door open unless I‚Äôm going on a main road to another cluster of stops. I leave the van on always in between stops, I pull the ebrake and put the van in drive at the same time. I don‚Äôt do this but some of my coworkers even just keep the ebrake slightly pulled up the whole route and keep the seat belt buckled and just pull the top over them before they go. Crazy part is they get rewarded for it

comment: At around 5:40 you talk about bosses using the old "I dunno" thing. My bosses do that too. I work EVS (janitorial) at a large hospital complex. We have a HUGE ass UV light we use to disinfect rooms. It's always breaking down. I have had patients lined up for rooms and the rooms needed UV Lighted and the light would completely die. I'd call them and ask "Ok, what do we do now?" "I dunno" was their answer, and they'd hang up. Hundreds of patients dying, screaming nurses, and I'm here like a dope with a broken UV light and haven't a clue what to do since LEGALLY we can't let anyone inhabit a contaminated room until it has been UV-lighted. I broke my right arm my punching it through a wall twice because of that scenario. Nowadays you know what I do? I just tell them I ran the light and let the next idiot discover it doesn't work.

comment: I've had to load bags a few times as a driver. The way it's set up, it is basically impossible to put things in the wrong bags. So if that happens, it's because you have lazy warehouse workers. The extra packages are not their fault, if they are technically on your route. If it's in a different city, then yeah, they're stupid. Those aid# labels are very important for that, as they are bagged based on letter group. And there is another thing on there "AX29" for example, which means it's on route 29. It's alot of work, but not as bad as being a driver. But I still would rather be a driver. Extra packages mean they skipped a step, and is not the fault of the bag loaders. But overall being a driver is terrible. Trying to meet time constraints of near impossibility. We recently shifted from residential to country side deliveries. And making 20 stops an hour is impossible. You have neighbors that are 1mile plus apart. Or you have all businesses, which are subject to heavy traffic. And wierdos who live on busy roads where the speed limit as soon as you leave the driveway is 55mph, like who thought that was okay?
label: Positive

comment: I am an Amazon customer. So drivers do delivery for me. If I order on Amazon Fresh then I have option to tip. I do tip. They say that driver gets all tips. I am happy about that. I am happy to note that most of your complaints were against dispatcher. And truth be told, neither you, nor your boss are Amazon employees. Both of you are sub contractors. So Amazon perks will not flow to you. Do not get me wrong. Amazon is a very hard company to work for. But tgey pay well. They sub contract to save money and that is where you got squeezed. In high tech society like America, your earning is proportional to your skills. You are young. More skills you learn, more you will make. Good luck.
label: Positive

comment:
They literally should hire an entire second fleet to reduce this work flow. If there's like 40 vans being loaded with this amount of packages, then they should hire 40 more to come in, load up and take off on the same hours to take off and deliver packages, so that the amount of work to deliver packages are split. 

In fact what they should do on top of that is hire 80+ Helpers to be with the primary and secondary fleets so that the driver can focus on driving and the Helper helps to divide and deliver the work flow so that both of them are able to make the stops and deliver packages safely.

I was just hired and on my first day alone I was thankfully delivering in an area I'm familiar with but I was expecting to at least be shadowed by a mentor for a week before they set me loose. If I had a helper I could've gotten through my delivery routes easier. I know they had me on what's called a "Nursery Route" but I still struggled with organization and slowed pace because it's Winter there's snow and ice on dangerous roads everywhere and it's my first time driving such a long vehicle that I'm not used to backing up in, I'm not comfortable going down dead-end roads where I'm gonna have to do a U-Turn to get out, I'd rather walk a quarter a half a mile to deliver a package safely than try to navigate my way by backing out which increases a risk of an accident just purely because I'm not used to backing out of a dead-end area in such a long van. The back-up camera helps, but I'm still not familiar with how long the van is to back up safely by myself -- I would've at least appreciated having a Helper to help navigate me safely out of areas since I can't even see around obstructed corners and hitting snow piles.

Hell I got stuck on my route once because of the snow and needed to be towed out.
label: Positive

comment: I did this for 3 months until i had enough and quit. They expect drivers to deliver to 190+ stops a day but what they dont tell you is they bundle locations together so those 190+ stops could actually be closer to 300 a DAY. Other delivery companies dont do this so the 190 stops you get at fedex are actually 190 stops and you can reasonably finish it. I was doing 85-160 stops a day which was almost 300 packages a day and about 150-200+ locations. If you cant do amazons 190+ stops a day they cut your hours but still expect you to come in knowing they wont let you drive "just in case someone doesnt come in". I drove 2 hours to get there quite a few times just to find out they didnt want me to drive and didnt tell me until i got there knowing damn well they have the routes the night before. In one of my last weeks. They had a route for me 1 day and the other 3 days they didnt and i only drove those days because someone didnt come in. The way i had to park and drive to make these deliveries was super sketchy and all the sketchy ass people i had to deal with finally pushed me over and i quit on the spot. I showed up every day and was never late. In return people made false reports about me to amazon and amazon wouldnt tell me what happened so i couldnt defend myself then they cut my hours but im still "full time" and get 40 hours a week but i actually got 30 or less.12 hours a day and i took home less money than my previous job because the hours per week were so low. When they announced we had to work 5 days a week for 2 weeks for prime day i immediately thought fuck this im leaving then quit 2 weeks before it started
label: Negative

comment: you absolutely know buddy is an absolute BEAST on his team, if he has 26 bags and 47 OF. if they staged his load properly...cart 1: 9 bags, cart 2: 9 bags, cart 3: 8 bags, carts 4 and 5: overflow (47 OF is A LOT) EDIT...if u arent marking pkgs with the sharpie like hes doing, youre doing it wrong lol it really is the best way. that 15 and 16 are BS! üòÇ it was definitely one of the most annoying parts of the job. when seasoned like he is, u see those and just do them out of order. but, sometimes the map wouldnt show the future stops, and i would be fuming pissed when sent back 2, sometimes 3 times üò°

comment: I have seen terrible management at aldi's where there is 20 people waiting in line to pay for their food, and there is only one register open, that is a sad statement about the management or mismanagement of that store, all Aldi stores. When I was 19 many years ago I worked at Kmart, when it was still around, I was doing overnight stocking, there was 7 guys doing that overnight shift . then one night I came into work and the head manager of that Kmart store greeted me at the door, I saw no cars in the parking lot which I taught it was very strange. So I asked the manager of the whole store where are the rest of the workers, he told me I was it. I took about 2 minutes to evaluate the situation, so I asked him a few questions, so you want me to do all the pallets and stock everything right? Yes he answered , and I am the only one here tonight, and the doors are locked and the alarm is on correct? Yes he answered. Well I told him, have a good night, you are the head of this store, you figure it out. I quit my job that moment and walked  out the doors. I went home laughing to myself and asking myself what the hell was wrong with that guy trying to pull that $hit on me. I went home and had a good sleep. I did not like what he tried to do, to get me stuck alone in a store. What would had happened If I had a medical emergency with no one to help me? I slept good, at that point I did not like what I saw management attept to do to me, so I went to college and earned a Bachelor's degree in International Business. That way if I get any job I can throw that degree in their face. I hate to hear that team leaders or managers mistreat workers. I like to see all the workers at all the amazon centers walk out at the same time in the U.S. imagine what would happen. Im glad you quit, its just a job not a career, good for you.
label: Negative

comment:
I just quit my job an hour ago. This job was horrible. They worked us like slaves. This warehouse was so bad that employees that came from Amazon said that they missed working at Amazon. 

I can‚Äôt believe I lasted as long as I did. They write you up for everything and anything. I got injured on the job and had to take a couple of days off because of excruciating back pain. Guess what? Write up. Every call out no matter the reason is a write up. 

Working there was awful. Having a good day? Not anymore hun. Look over your shoulder. Here comes the manager with a write up because you were at 99.9% rather than 100% 

They see you suffering and in pain and tell you to work faster. I‚Äôll never forget the sadistic smirk on my manager‚Äôs face as I was in excruciating pain and being told to work faster as a coworker who hadn‚Äôt done shit all day but stand by her and gossip stood there on their phone. 

The way they talked to us was horrible. Just last week a coworker of mine completely lost it and went off on the managers. She‚Äôs telling them about how poor their treatment of the employees is. We did so much work. They kept saying we hadn‚Äôt and proceeded to say that we had done less than what we did. What happened? They sat there smirking thinking it was amusing. Fast forward: They looked at our numbers after she told them off. Turns out we did much more than what they told us to.

My coworker fell down the stairs and got injured. Guess what? They wrote her up. She got in trouble for getting hurt!

Update: I quit and just had a job interview today. Two more lined up.
label: Negative

comment: They give them the number of scanners that was determined would be needed when they opened the facility.   Then they hire more people than they need because so many people don‚Äôt show up for work that they over staff. A lot of times people will realize that the place is chaos and make sure that they come in because they can goof off on the clock due to lack of equipment and understaffed supervision.   Plus they don‚Äôt want to pay for the staffing that it takes to keep track of the equipment.   You need someone to hand it out at the start of the shift, record who got what, then collect it at the end of the shift.  People will still try to hide it in their locker or just leave it on a shelf or something.  Because returning it so that someone else can do their job on the next shift is asking too much of them.  They need to clock out and get home to play video games.  That means that someone has to follow up and hold people accountable for not returning the equipment.  The lean experts don‚Äôt account for that when determining staffing.  It all takes time.  You would think that people would put equipment back where they are supposed to and put batteries into chargers, but they don‚Äôt.  Their idea of thinking about the future goes out as far as about 5 minutes.   Robots have been around for a long time.     They are expensive and require painful implementations.  Companies are getting them not to replace people.  They are getting them to do jobs that people won‚Äôt do.  They don‚Äôt call off once a week.   They don‚Äôt leave early.  They don‚Äôt get lost in the bathroom for 20 minutes.   They don‚Äôt quit after a week.  They even charge their batteries when needed.
label: Negative

comment:
The only real advice I have for anyone in this line of work is GO TO COLLEGE. Go to college, and you'll avoid being scammed into being legalized slave labor for the rest of your life. These brain-dead roles are for those who only have very basic job skills and no greater ambitions in life. Or ex-cons that did time in prison and are attempting to get back into the workforce. I chose to further my education after high school. Got my degree in science, and now I'm a full-time laboratory research specialist that sees more money in one day by preforming phlebotomy and conducting potentially life-saving case studies on animals, compared to what anyone in a warehouse earns in a single week moving boxes around.¬† So, it's pretty obvious what the greater decisions in life are when it comes to a job vs. an actual career. McDonald's isn't a "career" no matter how much they try to trick people into thinking it is, and neither is Amazon (unless you're the franchise owner or CEO of either). If you're a high school dropout that can barely read and write, then companies like this and many others don't have to give a rats ass about valuing you as an employee. And believe me when I say: (they don't). 
How much you get out of life depends on how much effort you put into it. So don't be lazy. Don't be a fuck-up. (Stay. In. School).
I see this issue coming up a lot with Millennials and the so-called "gen xers" of our workforce. And sorry, but I'm not with a hell of a lot of sympathy. A lot of them just don't want to bother with the academic work to go any further in life. And then they get all pissed off upon realizing the only types of jobs available to them are in things like warehousing. Well? What else do they expect?... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
If you enjoy warehouse work then all the power to you. I'm pointing out the people who end up in warehousing and just basically want to blame everybody else for being stuck at a job they hate. And yet you're the one that filled out the application. You're the one that went to the orientation (so you're fully aware of what you're getting yourself into). And you're the one that walked through the door and hit the amazon time clock. Nobody else put you there.. And even after working for only a few months, you'll blame management for not treating you nice by giving you a pat on the back or the golden key to the crapper for what you do. You guys even go so far as to blame customers like me that use amazon pretty regularly. And that doesn't make very much sense at all. Why should the customer be put to blame because someone hates their job at amazon? That's no different than going into a McDonald's and being treated like crap by the person at the cash register because they're unhappy with their "McJob." And all you did was ask for a coffee. Fair? (Not at all).
Remember, CUSTOMERS are the main reason why anyone serving in retail gets a paycheck in the first place. And that's better than nothing. If you don't like what you're doing then quit, enroll in classes and do the work necessary to get an actual career. You can walk right out the same door you walked in through at any time. You guys arn't prisoners...
label: Positive

comment:
Many people that have worked as amazon drivers have quit, and it's understandable why so many amazon drivers quit.  Lots of amazon delivery drivers that quit are hard workers, have a great work ethic, are great employees, are in great physical shape, etc.


Many amazon delivery drivers quit since they constantly feel pressured and rushed to make 200 stops per day and make 20 stops per hour.  At Amazon, many drivers have to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour, and they're being monitored to make sure they're making 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.  There's lots of circumstances that occur that make it hard or even impossible to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour such as traffic jams, detours, rainy conditions, delivering several packages to apartment complexes, customers asking questions about packages, etc.  Many amazon delivery drivers urinate in cups on the side of the road due to fearing that if they stop somewhere to use the bathroom, they won't be able to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.  Many amazon delivery drivers skip their breaks, run stop signs, run red lights, etc due to feeling rushed and pressured to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.
label: Positive

comment:
I just started.  Leadership all seems lost and clueless.  My biggest issue is that there wasn‚Äôt a member of HR in orientation (4 hrs) to answer basic questions.  The individuals I had to interact with were apparently on the ‚Äútraining path‚Äù. One was burned out and didn‚Äôt care to be helpful.  The other was brand new and didn‚Äôt know anything.

There is a complete lack of information at Amazon.  No one knows how anything works, or who to contact about issues.  They have a dry erase board where members can write suggestions on the board such as ‚Äúadd xyz food to the break room‚Äù but I don‚Äôt think suggestions are ever acted on by management

Since I‚Äôm in outbound ship dock it takes me about 5 minutes to walk to the front of the building.  Up front they have an immaculate break room full of coolers, lockers, video games, and a coffee machine.  The break room we have in the back is tiny, has a limited selection of anything, and there are definitely no games or tvs in it.  I also don‚Äôt think the sc‚Äùair conditioner works in it.  You could walk back out on the floor and be at least 10 degrees cooler.

Overall I‚Äôm not impressed.  Two days of being protected by training status and on the 3rd day they threw us to the wolves.  I honestly have a feeling they take bets and go out of their way to see who they can break and get to quit.  (Management) 

It‚Äôs also very clicky*, gossipy, and back stabbing.  Big red flag.  I don‚Äôt trust management and I damn sure don‚Äôt trust the guy working next to me.
label: Positive

comment:
I like this post, highly accurate. It's frustrating to not be able to get right to work when your station isn't properly maintained or your can't find the equipment to work with. I love how they can have girls in the lunchroom to pass around free beanies or tell you to stay 3 feet away from another person but they don't have someone by the clock machines outside HR to deal with errant punches of the clock which is an everyday occurrence and understandably, no HR person wants to manage this mispunch vs. missed punch happening. The app is in this regard, laughable. 

App notifications spewing Covid stats is mere virtue signaling. If they have 14 persons report testing + one day and prior or subsequent days it's only 1 or 2 + ... That ain't got nothing to with contracting the virus at work. The messaging would be that they are overly atop the situation but yes, it's creepy when someone from a pillar whispers "thanks for wearing your mask" as you head for a much needed meal break. 

You wanna give me a beanie, Amazon? On MLK Day just gimme the "I have a dream" imprint black beanie. 

I had Covid, it's real. I causes lost money for sure. I worked a year in 2020 with Doordash, never got the virus but I did when I got home from family members who were not safe about passing it around like their aren't variants. 

After one week with Amazon, I made my peace with it, I saw positive things and I recognized things that needed to be addressed and realized I couldn't do anything about it. I will likely leave the company in one week. I made it known on their stupid little questionnaires that they had a multitude of issues and that their training was average at best. They really don't give you a fair amount of materials to feel comfy with your role(s).

comment:
Mcdonald's isn't something you should be asking for $20 an hour while starting a family.

btw, just so i dont have to respond back to anyone. if you didn't understand this. you didn't get the point. You can start at Amazon Warehouse straight out of high school graduation with passing C- grades. People shouldn't be starting families with those wages. Plus, Amazon has a 3 year step pay program and has annual pay increase for inflation. It's as Jeff Bezos said, this job isn't supposed to be permanent. It's temporary to get a higher education/career.

in 2022 January, I started off at $18.25 + 1.50 night shift. Today, still with Amazon March 2025, I'm at $22.15 + 1.50 night shift. For those who are blue badge for 3 years right now, you get paid $23.65 + 1.50 for $25.15 total as of March 2025.

Tons of Overtime, shift swap one weekend per month and 1 weekday per week, 80 hours PTO, 8 hours Vacation(extra 40hours per year on blue badge, max 128 per year capped at 160hours), and 170+ hours UPT (you can gain more with Overtime) with max cap 80hours. You also get AT LEAST 15 days UNPAID LEAVE for a total of 90 days per calender year. 3, no questions  asked bereavement per year with 4 months apart(otherwise you need proof). Want extra 30 minutes break? you can do that with your time off options. Want to come in 2 hours late? sure, use your time wisely. How about leave 2 hours late? no problem! We also have career choice. People mainly get their education here for RME roles, mangement positions, tech field, and CDL truck driver.

or simply to build a resume and have multiple types of training in multitudes of departments and become a Problem solver role or Learning Ambassador teaching new hires, etc. or become a Safety Associate in the Safety Community.

Other warehouses nearby are paying $23-28 but dont have the similar benefits and you MUST COME TO WORK or you're fired.
label: Positive

comment:
Holdddd up... did you say "The first 30 minute break"...? You guys get 30 minute breaks? We get 15 min breaks :l
Oh and toxic traits you missed: 
The ones that think their 'vest color' or title lets them sit around not doing shit all day. They're the same managers that will start pushing employees to speed up when we're short staffed/behind on work. If we're that far behind- pick up a box!
The ones that will pair good employees to work with the bad employees to 'balance out the work'. NO! Hold the slow workers accountable, and don't make us pick up their slack!
And... the overly social managers... the ones that will stop and socialize with 1-2 employees for about 15-30 minutes at a time. People shouldn't get paid to hang out while other people are busting their ass... those same social managers know which of their friends want VTO for the day so if you need/want to go home that day, you're in line behind their friends.
label: Negative

comment: That's exactly why I left Amazon. I'm glad you're discussing this. Those lousy managers wouldn't talk about it which really pissed me off. That's lousy management. I was an N.C.O. in the marine Corp. Here's a tip for you. Leadership is more effective by example not barking orders.
label: Negative

comment:
Throughout my time in Pick (I lasted only two days), I had zero physical interaction with my manager. However, he was known to exhibit the first three toxic manager traits. 
The managers I had after moving to pack were the mostly good managers. The first of my pack managers fits number 4 of the toxic manager traits to a certain extent but for the most part was a generally good manager and did now screw around when it came to his position. 
The one that came after him initially came off as a really good manager, and at one point was one of the managers I liked the most.
Despite being soft spoken, he seemed fun to be around. But overtime he showed his true colors of the toxic manager. His toxic manager traits though are nothing like the traits mentioned in the video (excluding number 1). His traits in this case involved giving dirty looks and being rude to coworkers. This happened at random times. He's even showed signs of being passive aggressive in the form of having talked about a coworker behind their back and ultimately what he did to me that led up to my firing. The final manager I had up until I left fit all the four good traits to a T. She was more direct and seemed to be more eager, a polar opposite of the person she replaced.
As with most managers, most of the managers in my building were all guilty of toxic trait number 1, regardless of whether or not they are generally good. The roadblocks in this case even go as far as medical conditions or injuries.
label: Positive

comment:
Hello Nathan, I learned something very important to do in stowing when you beginning your day, after you return from your 1st and 2nd break. As soon as you sign into your station scan an item no matter if a pod has not arrived. Your time  begins as soon as you clock in when you get to the wearhouse and as soon as you finish with your first break. And I know this is true because I reviewed an entire day with my manager from beginning to end. They know if I'm working or not every minute you are on the clock; every minute!
As you know we have a second break of 30 minutes where you don't have to clock out. One day I had no work before my break. In the system it showed that I had taken a 38 minute break. This reason was because the computer counts your last scan till your next scan no matter if you had nothing to stow. So in conclusion, it's man vs the computer clock at Amazon.
label: Positive

comment:
The manager handing out stacks sounds to me like she was newer or didn't understand the system. I've heard (not entirely sure), that generally anytime that you're not doing your assigned path is actually considered system side as TOT. This includes your breaks and if you've been positioned out to do a critical path, which is why PAs and managers make a really big deal about making sure that you're scanned in order to do that stuff. Some of this information was even available to associates (which some learning ambassadors would use for assessing performance improvement plans).

At least the way it was explained to me a while back, associates are given an allotted amount of time they can have for TOT, and anything that is flagged in the system essentially has to get reviewed by a manager or signed off on. 

Worst managers I've seen have been outbound managers with megaphones yelling at associates to get back to work after breaks the entire shift.
label: Negative

comment:
I had a boss who would make us dinner and was always joking. I realize now my humor caused others to joke with me in ways i wasnt okay with but would only later addres it in what i see as now wrong. 

I was breast feeding at work. He made a comment s about my circumstances . I dont think i know how to handle direct confrontation with someone in .. power.. i think i reported him rather then directly .. 

I later missed that boss. His name was Griffin which i attribute now to ‚Äúgriffen‚Äôdoor‚Äù   

I don't like who i am and I wish i had skills in handling things differently.   Im in counseling to figure out.. but back then i wish i had taken into account Him as a whole rather thrn something in the moment that angered me enough to tell on him. 

This was a pervasive problem in my life.. i also see that i wasnt approachable when i was in a power seat.. which is likely the karma that came around. If i used my power in a way that made others feel like they could not confront me or ask directly.. it came out in ways of someone going to my boss and me getting fired or let go.  Now i think silencing others in even subtle ways is wrong and Want to out the bully i was and the karma that came around but not in a pattern i could see quickly enough. Now that i see and understand.. im doing my best to confess it and change my behavior. 

When i got scared.. i would use what i thought of as protective measures (like telling someone) but would not do that on myself when i see now others were intimidated by me.   

I hope to be given opportunities to demonstrate that to no longer be true. But in that pattern.. i feel ashamed and wish i knew appropriate ways to be :act/ engage or make better future choices that dont cause others to feel bad.

comment:
A prerequisite to what this guy is saying is having a strong mind.  

Managers get fired and or replaced all the time.  So yes, think of the toxic boss as a blueprint of whom not to be because believe it or not, their time is ticking. 

It also helps if you have connections into the Top Brass of your Company and throughout your industry.

I recently experienced a toxic Boss getting fired.  Everybody that's been working under him for more than a year already saw it from a mile away.  The problem is often that the Toxic Boss will think too highly of him or herself whilst brushing off the Team's need.

That being said, I did a lot of what this guy is saying without even thinking too hard about it because it's just a normal part of my personality.  I never base my worth or value on what another person thinks.  Only what I think of myself.
label: Positive

comment:
I can't say my boss is really bad. He's very intelligent but has an issue explaining in detail what he wants out of you. I feel like I'm in a guessing game always losing. I'm a hustle type worker lady who came out of the hvac residential install as a lead so I was training guys and some of the nastiest slum areas. Not only did I have to stand my ground to fit in with nothing but guys, but I had to train them. They didn't always meet me with kindness. We always want to learn from a girl. I've never had a lead position where I'm not allowed to be a lead. When people are slacking, I give them something to do and let them know. I'm acknowledging their lack of give you know what. If it's repeated, I go to the bosses and let them know that I no longer want them working with me. I don't wanna train somebody on a job that doesn't wanna learn. I've never had any issues with bosses on that. They don't want slackers because they're being paid to actually do some work.
This boss hired me as a lead eight months later I finally realized he's been hinting to me the whole time, but he feels like I'm trying to do his job . My boss doesn't come out of the office barely ever because he's got a lot of office work and he does a lot of the blueprints for our computers and machinery to work together. The head fabricator did not want the lead position and now I know why. My boss is very picky with the looks of our work in that part. I am 100% with him. Him and I were trained by the same instructors and the union for hvac. We only about a year I think. Anyway, in the interview, I expressed my way up being a lead and the CEO no, my boss the manager I'm talking about seem to have a problem with the way I do things. Actually, the manager insisted on having me work with him and he needed me because I knew hvac. I don't know industrial curbs for commercial rooftop unit units. I do not know metal bending machinery because I did all mine by hand. I did residential not commercial. I never welded but now I've been learning for a year and doing very well. My boss always compliments on how hard I work and I'm the only one in there he can trust to actually clean the shop because everybody else will mess around and not clean. When it needs to be done, he makes sure I'm free to do it and I'm being paid so I don't care. He has me certain projects because he doesn't trust the other guys to do it correctly without smashing finger or damaging product. I see these other new guys standing there when they're not being directed to do anything. They run out of work. They literally just walk around and stand around like lost puppy dogs. When I'm done with my stuff, I run right over to all of them on their projects and ask if I can lend a hand and usually they hand me the crappy stuff they have. I get it done because believe me there's not one thing in that shop that will ever compete with what I've done in the field lol we're talking the gravy of gravy. What irks me as I went to my boss several times because he's not out there on the floor. I let him know your guys are just standing around doing nothing. Avoiding is what it is. He pretty much does not care. He's told me things like they don't piss us enough here. He's made all kinds of excuses why he hasn't taught me the stuff in the office that the CEO things he's teaching me. I'm a lead that's supposed to be in the office apparently. I'm out fabricating and I have been now going on a year. I have maybe 15 minutes worth an office work per week. This guy is such a control freak. He's not even teaching me this stuff that him and the CEO talked about. He'll flat out tell me he needs me because I can keep him organized, but then he doesn't even let me do the stuff that I'm supposed to be doing. I'm all kinds of confused. Like what I never worked anywhere that wants to pay people big bucks and not even care if they're actually working. Before I found out I wasn't supposed to be lead lol I know that's confusing cause I'm a lead. OK! Something is going on pretty goofy. I don't know if this guy is bipolar or what it is, but I can tell you something he does like to manipulate. He tells me about the compliment sandwich. I don't have a compliment sandwich. I just tell him quit fucking off and get to work. He tells me first you give a compliment and then you give them the dagger and then you go back to the compliment. Well, this guy is so brilliant most of the time but he doesn't realize he's giving me a secret and now I know when he's playing his little games on me. This is all kind of toxic, but I'm gonna ride the wave because I make really good money here. I stopped trying to be the lead, even though I'm a lead. I'm not gonna help these other guys anymore because they avoid me when I could use a hand because the boss says he doesn't care if you fuck off right so I'll just fuck off. Excuse my language, but you see where I'm going here. You start letting certain people slack and the hard workers see that stuff they're not gonna be all happy about it. Why should I bust my butt if these guys aren't and I can still get paid the same too. You wonder why the guys are always calling in sick we're not showing up and taking an extra days even predicting they're gonna be sick for extra days. Lol I say he asked for that because he's being too relaxed. I don't think you have to drill or pound on anybody who is working hard, but I do think you need to put a little pep to their step when they're not doing anything. How are we gonna teach these young guys to hustle a little bit and get up there in the world because they're not gonna do a drag in their shoes across the shop looking like they don't even wanna be there. 
Sorry, I just have to go  somewhere to vent and here I am. I don't know my generation did not tolerate not bringing your ambition to work. I can't bring it to myself just start messing around because everybody else's. I'm just talking a lot of mad right now a little bit irritated. 
I was told today I was intentionally being thrown to the wolves. Yeah he found out that's how I learned my trade. He likes to fatigue me pretty hard too, but I never see them out there even checking on the new guys. We had his head guy come try to show me right in front of him something and he blew up on the poor guy. Apparently he doesn't like grinding to fix things. See things only work when it's convenient for him is what I am finding out. He'll come and critique me up and down, but doesn't even check on the newer dude. I found out today by the trucker that one of their two by fours let loose. Nobody told the boss so I made sure to tell them. Funny none of my boards go down the road. Oh well. That's why they leave me to do that stuff. The guy is avoid it because it's hard Work in their opinion. To me hard work is claiming belly up underneath somebody's floor with the floor 1 inch away from your nose and probably 20 feet in. Somebody has to take a saw to the area. I think you are just in case there's an emergency and they need to get you out. Hopefully they don't cut you in the process because they can't see where you are. Lol but these guys think it's hard work to take a drill bit and just drill their standing in a nice cozy shop. Give me a break.

comment:
Dealing with this right now. Best advice I have is to write down your frustrations, but DO NOT talk to your bad manager while you are angry. Instead, save your thoughts for later and bounce them off of someone less emotionally close to the situation who can help you spin all the problems you‚Äôve identified into positive solutions. 

For instance, I was so mad at my boss last night I hardly slept. I knew I was going to get reprimanded in the morning for making a mistake when I had been set up to fail via an unreasonable workload and insufficient training. I wrote down all my angry thoughts about the root of the issue and how the company was poorly managed, but when I had calmed down a little, I shared my thoughts with my husband and asked him to help me figure out how to handle the situation without being a doormat or getting fired. His advice helped me remember that all communication is just negotiation. In other words, I had to pitch what I wanted as a solution to what my boss wanted. This way, I turned what could have been a very negative blame-game meeting with my manager into a more positive ‚Äúus vs. the problem‚Äù meeting. 

The environment still sucks, and I‚Äôm still looking for another job for the sake of my physical and mental health, but this approach has helped me at least manage my manager enough to maintain a decent working relationship until I can find another job (hopefully soon üò¨).
label: Negative

comment:
My current situation is really annoying. I don‚Äôt want to go to the union and get higher ups involved but soon I might have to. 
I‚Äôm a cleaner, I have a area manager and a janitor/manager who are married. 

First of neither of them speak clear English so I get in trouble every now and then because of them. They will ask me to do something, I‚Äôll do it, days later I get a message from my area manager asking why I didn‚Äôt do it and she‚Äôll get rude and angry saying passive aggressive stuff like "why is it so hard for you to do what we ask" she‚Äôll say I did one thing but not another, something she didn‚Äôt mention to me in person. They gaslight and lie to make me look bad. 

Second I‚Äôm pretty certain the janitor has mental health issues or something going on in his life that causes him to have mood swings. One second he‚Äôs happy, next he‚Äôs in a power mood nitpicking and complaining about pointless stuff. There‚Äôs been times where he‚Äôs been in a very bad mood and takes it out on the cleaners. 

Third, they don‚Äôt listen or help when I say stuff like "I don‚Äôt have time" they will give me more and more jobs to do but no extra time to do it in then complain when I don‚Äôt do it. They‚Äôll say "find the time" or "that‚Äôs not our problem" 

Fourth, they are clearly picking on me. There‚Äôs other cleaners but I‚Äôm the only one who gets moaned at about things others don‚Äôt. I have "dirty toilets" but I can visibly see mine are cleaner than others I‚Äôve used elsewhere. I‚Äôll ask other cleaners if they‚Äôve been moaned at and they‚Äôll say no. If my toilets were dirty I‚Äôd get complaints but I don‚Äôt. I only have my managers wanting everything to be spotless but only me, only my area. No one else gets the ocd treatment.

comment:
Sometimes, you have no choice but to quit and where I am, it's mind blowing how many places will take a guy who lets say clearly has big issues, and put him in a position of control over others. I do know that my interactions with that guy are not even remotely the same as the interactions with the people above him. When I say him I mean 2 different managers and technically 1 woman I have encountered over the last 1.5 years. 

The woman was only a week she wasn't even a manager technically but she was certifiably "out there", ignorant, unpleasant, not much going on upstairs or anywhere for that matter and that wasn't just my opinion. 1 week.

The two guys had a lot in common. Extremely strikingly similar. Both were 43-55 years old. They both had a slew of issues. Really really bad marriages  and divorces. One of them told me crack was his d of choice. Not was, but is. I clarified. 5 kids, the youngest severely autistic. Ex wife had just as many issues. I cant say for sure about this guy but it seemed to me had was more of just a bad drunk as opposed to a bad manager. Always in a bad mood, picking fights over nothing. Extremely insecure over me, a single man, late 40's, no real issues in life, no kids, nothing to tie me down, good worker, the people at the top offering to get me training and higher grade licence (that is the way licence is spelled in Canada). He was insecure and with too many issues.

The other guy was exact same thing, different pile. Broken relationships, kids he couldn't afford, breeding, putting more of himself out there for future generations as if anyone needs that. Ex-Wife's gambling addictions, absolutely napoleon complex, OCD, no filter with anyone, obviously didn't have great influence in life. This guy would underestimate me too which I would would show him up every time, and he would be bothered that I showed him up. When he couldn't get rid of me legit, by setting me up to fail, which I didn't, that's when he would get sneaky. The problem wasn't my work it was that he was intimidated by me. He couldn't be unhinged with me. so they find a way.

The other interesting thing is that neither of these 2 "men" 43-55 held a drivers licence. For one reason or another but it is something they had in common which in this town/city, is unusual.  and both were completely OCD, in their own words and actions. The first guy I'm sure has at least one impaired charge.  As to why the other little guy with Napoleon Complex didn't hold one, who knows? He could be an ex addict who lost it that way too? Gamblers addicts and alcoholics. He says he just let it go, I'm not sure I believe that. These guys both brought their problems to work. I think that's what it came down to. It's like the lyric in that song Flagpole Sitta by Harvey Danger (which absolutely describes the second guy) "Been around the world and found, That only stupid people are breeding, The cretins cloning and feeding". What baffles me though is who is putting these people in a Manager Position? Sometimes, you can't just stay. Personally, I can't be around someone like these people. I'm chill. I used to get worked up, I'm chill. You blow your top, I'm chill these days, especially if I know I'm right. You go ahead and lose your mind, let everyone know you're unhinged, I'm gonna chill. I think when you get to a point where they are throwing things at you, and you are showing them up, they are loosing it over nothing and you are chill, when they can't get you legitimately they move on to more covert and underhanded methods. UNLESS you deem it not worthy of your time and presence and you move on and I don't know what it is, why does it seem like every "manager" in the industry I am in (not tech) seem to be broken in the head? Where do people get the energy to fight, argue, stress over the petty?
label: Negative

comment:
It doesn't sound to me like you've ever really dealt with a truly toxic, narcissistic,  manipulative manager.  There is a difference between a bad manager and one who is truly evil.  These strategies do not work with a narcissistic manager who is targeting you or looking to escape accountability by throwing their employees under the bus to hide their own mismanagement.  

Take motivation on how you don't want to be?  That doesn't help your immediate situation in any way.  And if you're a decent human being to begin with,  you don't need to live with abuse from a toxic manager to know how not to act. 

Empathize with why they might be acting how they are? There are truly toxic people that act how they do in a calculating way.  For example, what about managers who are just malicious and choose to falsely accuse their employees of things in order to cover their own bad behavior?  Some managers just use their employees as disposable pawns to avoid accepting responsibility for their own actions. 

Kill them with kindness, using the examples given here?  In my experience dealing with any narcissistic individual,  this type of response is viewed by them as weakness,  and they will twist your kindness around and use it to attack you later, and will also increase their abuse because they know you're responding out of fear to try to keep the peace, which they don't care about.  

Don't take it personally?  When dealing with a manager as I've described above, it IS personal.  You are targeted,  a victim of their bullying and abuse.  And YOU pay the price through loss of your physical, mental, and emotional well-being, not to mention the eventual loss of the job and income. It is highly personal.

The only strategy here that may help is setting boundaries, but that was barely mentioned.  And when there is a mismatched power dynamic where one person is in authority over you, all it might do is buy you some time.

Your best bet is to document everything, CYA, look for a new job, and leave as soon as you can.  And if you get enough documentation about their bad behavior,  flip the table and file charges against them (but be prepared for a fight).
label: Negative

comment: All Directors are toxic so there's no escaping, how do you deal?

comment: I'm currently working for a small business that has 2 owners. Let me prefice by saying, I'm actually not quite sure how this company is still in business. They're consistently on site working together amongst other employees. These 2 owners/bosses are always arguing with each other in front of employees, as well as the customers we're working for. Because I'm new, I'm always being demeaned in front of coworkers and the customers. I'm more qualified than the owners of the company, and several times throughout the work week, I'll bring up issues that need to be addressed, only to be told I'm inexperienced and I don't know what I'm talking about. Of course, the issues rear their head, and it becomes a giant issue that could've been fixed, but now my 2 bosses are running around like psychopaths on the work site. Instead of being acknowledged that I should've been listened to, their egos and insecurities dictate them doubling down on the demeaning, micromanaging, and disrespect towards me. On several occasions, I've been privy to customers telling my bosses that they are extremely unprofessional and should look for a different field to make a living in. In the process of them arguing with each other and micromanaging me, they also are making more mistakes than any of the other employees have time to fix.  I've worked in some pretty toxic work places over the years, but this environment is maybe top 5 most toxic work situations of all time, in history, for everyone. So, long story longer, I've tried to salvage or fix a toxic boss by using them to my advantage, and it just doesn't work. That strategy is just prolonging the inevitable. My advice is to just start your exit plan immediately like your life depends on it, and execute. Good luck out here in the work force folks, it's dog eat dog. Thanks for letting me vent  üòÇ ‚úåÔ∏è.

comment:
I worked at Amazon in 2008 and in 2009. It's as bad as he is saying and worse the bathroom and lunch area is on one side of the building and they would have us meeting after break on the complete opposite side of the building. You seriously had 10 minutes to heat up your food eat it use the bathroom. Only thing was there was two microwaves for 200 people to use. There was only one bathroom. We would not only get hit with mandatory overtime but they would also do mandatory time off. So you would go to work expecting to work a full shift and after a few hours they would send you home. There were weeks I would work 10 hours expecting to work 38.

Amazon monitors everything you do and say. The one time I had to go for a crap after lunch I was away from my workstation for 15 minutes. When I came out of the bathroom my manager was waiting outside for me and asked me why I was in the bathroom so long. I was legitimately taking a dump. He told me I need to take bathroom breaks either during my lunch break or my other brakes. I explained to him even with the bathroom breaks I take I still make my numbers so what does it matter how long I'm gone if I make in the quota.

And about that quota. The vast majority of Amazon employees are temps so they don't get benefits. Those quotas are there because if they're met the people actually hire through Amazon get a bonus at the end of the week. The Temps don't get any of that money. So you have a place where 90% of the workers are temps doing the work that creates a bonus and the 10% of Amazon employees get the money. That's why management is always up your butt about quotas and micromanaging everything you do

comment: LOL at Amazon, if you‚Äôre late by a few minutes, or you clock out a few mins before your shift ends, you have to use your paid time because you can use that in minute increments. If you use unpaid time, then you have to use that in hour increments so if you get to work 5 mins late, you might as well not clock in for another 55 mins. Or if you want to leave early and you only have unpaid time, then you leave up to an hour early. I used to never let my unpaid time get under 3 hours. It was aggravating though because you only get 20 unpaid hours quarterly. You get paid and vacation time biweekly until i think May or June.

comment:
I've done warehouse work for years. I've never tried Amazon warehouse only their sortation center, but dont ever plan to try again. Its too different from the Order Selecting I do for grocery stores.

For us, shifts start at a certain time, but dont end till all the work is completed. Average day is 10 hours, but can extend all the way to 14 or so. 2- 15 min breaks, 1- 30-45 min lunch (your choice on length as long as its in the 30-45 min range) and a 3rd break if night gets too long.

On your feet all day, riding on electric pallet jacks, grabbing cases and placing them on your pallets. Wrapping the pallet and dropping it off at the door. And repeat. The most variety comes from what type of order you get assigned. 

And of course, assignments are timed. But they are pretty easy once you get effiecent, decently strong and know how to stack properly. 

Then the pay is alot better.

$20/HR base
Night premium, weekend premium, cooler or freezer premium
Production incentive if you are faster than the order time. Up to 30% of base pay.

Personally I really like warehouse work, but its not something I want to do for life. I just thought I would comment how things work in a place other than Amazon because I've always been curious why I see people constantly complain about how they run their warehouses. I always figured the getting timed thing was standard practice. Granted, this work isnt for everyone, only about 10% of a given set of trainees will actually stick around past 6 months.

comment:
I was sent to Seattle for AD1 in August of last year, LEW in October of last year, and resigned this February. I am so thankful for the opportunity, experience in leadership, and the diverse group of people I met, but I sucked at being an Area Manager at Amazon. On top of it, there was pressure from different corners. I worked FHN in a fulfillment center and boy, it wasn't very easy for me. I don't want to go into detail because it will be a book, so I will hit the basics. A few tenured AAs think you can't say anything to them when coached.
On top of that, Ops kept piling things on our plates and grading us like school students. I hated doing KNETs and Curiosity, which were never-ending. We did Instacleans every Wednesday, which we got graded on, too. You are thrown into your role without having someone physically show you. It's business. The little things you do don't go into account. What kept me there was my team of coworkers, whom I cherish dearly. I had a knowledgeable PA, but I felt a lot of pressure from him in terms of being on the floor consistently and being involved. A lot of us worked more than 10 hours pretty much every day. Internal leaders know so much, and even though you try not to level up to them, you feel like you aren't doing much. I felt pressure around me for not doing enough or not understanding my role. I felt stupid. I am not going back.
label: Positive

comment: I am working in amazon for 2 years, I've started my journey as team leader, later on i've passed panel for L4. From perspective my experience and also my friends I totally agree with statement that amazon it's not a good place for people who doesnt like changes. You can't get too attached to a department/process and people because in a week you might find out that you are on a different shift, department or process. Unfortunately, most managers get burnt out at the beginning by too much information, too many tools but above all by not knowing the process, which is sometimes complicated. My advice. At the beginning try to understand the process, observe a lot and don't get used to where you are haha. Everything is depending about in what site are u working at. Old site or young site? I've launched 2 sites  and of course it gives great satisfaction but it is mega tiring. As for stepping into a new role, you need to be prepared for a large number of tools, which can be overwhelming at first. As an area manager there are lots of little things that take up a lot of your time and can sometimes be frustrating. Then there are the big things like introducing new processes and departments which are also very rewarding. I would compare working at amazon to riding a rollercoaster, there are moments when it is extremely hard and tough, there are moments when it is lighter and duller, but the end result is that the work gives great satisfaction and is addictive. You need to be flexible ;) Take care for all of you guys and dont give up!
label: Positive

comment:
It's our fault that things are this bad now.  We enable this shit through our consumption and our supply of employment and we think, "Well I'm not suffering so who gives a shit?"

When every company catches onto the fact that despite such poor working conditions, consumers will continue to support the company through their labor and consumption because their need for new stuff outweighs their suffering, these companies will change their business models to the same structure.  And then guess what?  EVERYBODY will suffer.   And once that happens, it's VERY difficult to go back.  

So stop consuming from them or atleast reduce your consumption.  And stop working for them.  Stop participating.  If everyone collectively does this, these companies will lose sales revenue which will freak out their investors and the whole company will go downhill fast.  The power is  STILL with the people if they collectively used it.

comment: The thing about TOT is that if you do your job and do it well then your TOT doesn't matter. I get my numbers every night pretty much and I have plenty of TOT and I have never once been talked to about the TOT. I do have bad days like everyone else but I do my job well and I care about my job so its looked at that way and nothing is said. The fact is that some people are not cut out for fast work and assembly line type work. Some people just will never be able to do it. They then complain about how a company was unfair to them and had unrealistic expectations. You should have realized after a week that maybe this work isn't for you and move on to a different type of job. I am not saying that every former Amazon employee is lying. I'm tired of people thinking everything Amazon is just so horrible and slave labor. Its' not. The pay is great. The benefits are great. comment:
Oh. My. God. I thought it was just me. The are days when I have to just stop working and go to the bathroom to just cry. The work is so hard. It's like working out at the gym for 10 hours a day. I have to constantly drink water to stay hydrated, but we're not allowed to go to the bathroom as often as you need. If we do the clock will start ticking. 
We get two 15-minute breaks and one 30-minute break. In actuality, I we get 5 minutes to get to the bathroom, 5 minutes to use the bathroom,  5 minutes to get back to our work station. No time to eat. On the 30-minute break, we get 15 minutes to eat, 5 minutes to use the bathroom, 5 minutes to wash up with a baby wipe, put deodorant( yes, we are sweating that much) and 5 minutes to get back in production. Keep in mind that I am 58 years old, what's sciatica and just recovered from covid-19. With no prospects I'll find you a better job in the future. Working for Amazon was the worst mistake I ever made in my life.

comment:
I love the ones trying to compare their jobs to this, oh and those suck it up buttercup.. hilarious. All the while none of these same people have ever worked inside the facilities. And anyone who has and said that it was easy, either you're just loving the taste of that boot, or you are one of the ones who is about to become "customer" at your facility. It's work. Hard work. It's REPETITIVE. It's not, carry a beam up a ladder and then sit tf down for 20 minutes. It's carry the beam up the damn ladder, for 4 hours straight over and over, with no time to stop, no down time, no time to collect a thought. Going to the bathroom will screw your entire rate system up. Working in a fulfillment center has shown me just how precious 8 minutes really is and how quickly it can get you in trouble. 

I work 4 10 hour grave yard shifts. Sure, I can prepare a meal at home, ya know...all that good protein we need for the thousands of calories I can burn in Just one single night. But chances of me being able to actually heat that up, in a very time checked 30 minutes, waiting in line of other folks, is almost slim to none in my facility. By the time I do get to sit, I'm scarfing it all down, in an unhealthy pace. I don't even chat on my phone or message anyone on my breaks because I'm literally just sitting there trying to decompress. 

If we are away from our station for more than 5 minutes, our TOT is beginning to calculate and we are only allowed 30 whole minutes a night, in a 600,000 square feet building. If we need water, sometimes we aren't stationed next to a close nearby water station, and thus that factors into it too. Every thing is HEAVILY calculated, watched, and configured to where it's unsafe in alot of matters. 

We've had heart attacks, heat strokes, people just passing out, on the work floors due to the work load and how FAST we have to go. This video does not realistically represent the amazon warehouse life. We do all of that, but 10 times faster. I'm a picker, and I'm forced to pick bare minimum of 425 items an hour. That is if my robotic pods are working correctly, no drives bomb out, station doesn't break down a million times, oh and...I don't leave my station. A normal employee...it's hard to hit that rate. Amazingly I have awesome managers at mine but they are honest that it's not easy to hit those numbers and it is rarely done. 

I also average 15,000 steps a night, but have hit that 30k a time or two! I've also injured myself. Twice. All due to the extremely fast work pace. Unfortunately, I also have a central nervous disease, but it's a pattern with Amazon employees. There will be a day where I won't be able to walk anymore. I spend my 3 days off in pain. Not just a little work pain, but physically debilitating unnecessary pain. Nobody should have to work like that. There are many nights I struggle and am so miserably in pain, that I've almost thought to walk out. But I can't. I have a little mouth to feed.
label: Negative

comment: Everyone needs to remember this about Amazon drivers.. they don't actually work for Amazon.  They were for different separate DSP's who are contractors for Amazon.  Drivers paychecks do not come from Amazon, they come from the Delivery Services Provider who they actually drive for.  Yeah, they have vans with Amazon logos and uniforms with Amazon all over them.. but they work for the DSP.  FedEx does the same thing.  One reason is so you can't unionize drivers like UPS did.  Another reason is to keep wages low.

 Why?
 Becsuse kerping each DSP fairly small will msjebit virtually impossible to Unionize them. If for example tne Teamsters msnaged to unionize obe DSP, it wouldn't be enough to csuse any real chsnge. Then that DSPs contract would be terminated!

comment: I do not agree with the statement "a job is a job." Sure, it may be a thing to do for money, but you don't get a living wage, the work conditions are utterly atrocious, the expectations and workload are asinine and the constant fear of job security or threats by management increase stress levels, as well as the long hours. The dilemma is folks need money to survive so they feel trapped to work for these abysmal companies, and, if they need to work these shitty jobs to survive they lose time with family, their health is at risk, they can't get ahead financially etc. We need real solutions to these dilemmas, not bullshit nor telling people to suck it up and suffer or get a second shitty job. It's time for this kind of stupidity to disappear.

comment:
Amzn really not that bad. Come to work, do your job, get paid. Nice systems in place to cover you if necessary that I feel are innovative or at least I haven‚Äôt seen anywhere else. 

- PTO upfront after every shift
Usable immediately 

- UPT (unpaid time) accrual to also be used for any event you feel is necessary 

- Scheduling additional shifts at your leisure, bonus pay for additional shifts when available through app.

-All personal aspects handled through the app. PTO/UPT requests, time edits, additional shift requests, internal job changes, personal/mental health resources, etc.

You really don‚Äôt have issues until you start to finesse the system, using unpaid time you don‚Äôt have going negative, calling off, not working effectively, etc

I had spinal issues brought on by work, but they never put me on the line for light lifting that the Doctors suggested. The other is an labour share task ICQA. I had a year and a half of bad ratings, and I kept saying that 'I can't do it due to Learning Difficulties, best to train me on something I can do.' Nope, my memory was getting worse, months of meetings, HR protecting Managers best interests, Doctors notes, OH looking at other avenues, and it just went to nowhere. 
I decided enough is enough. 
Amazon cares very little about their workers, if they don't find a use or you can't do what they push on you then they can discard you.
Getting away from that has been good for me mentally.
label: Positive

comment: I've been working at Amazon for about 6 months.  I'm  white trans person and as soon as I was able to at 3 months I promoted to a quality auditor, then a month after that I made Quality Lead Auditor, I've already been told once I'm comfortable in my current job I'll be promoting to a Learning Ambassador.  Then after Learning Ambassador I'll shoot for Process Assistant.   So at least at my warehouse I've found incredible upward mobility.  Everyone complains that doing the basic jobs are shit, but no one wants to ask for new opportunities.   I went into Amazon because no one in my area was hiring but I had heard the horror stories.   Truth is, if you're someone who can be on your feet 10 hours a day, move with a sense of urgency and don't try to get out of work when you are clocked in Amazon is a fine a pretty okay place to work.   I haven't heard about this 3 year thing and I know plenty of people who have been there far longer than that.  I suspect the fact that I come from the military and have been doing labor since I was a kid plays a large part in my success there.  I bug my managers near daily about learning new things as soon as I get bored of what I know.  Honestly if they just played music in the warehouse all the time I'd say it was one of the best jobs I've ever had.  I don't have anyone but an objective computer breathing down my throat and rate is really easy to make once you learn the job.  I think they could increase the required rate a little slower though, give people 3 months instead of 5 weeks to hit rate.  I do believe that $17.65 an hour that they pay at my Warehouse is undervaluing the work we do.  They also need to remove the cap on raises at 3 years.  You can get raises beyond but you have to promote to at least Process Assistant.
label: Positive

comment:
please note that this is just for my sight and may not apply to all amazon fulfillment centers.

also, remember that: AMAZON IS ALL ABOUT SAFETY! 
This is why that's BS. plus other stories.



1: full time employees have to work two years before being able to apply for a manager position. this doesn't stop you from learning other jobs, but only a few actually give extra pay. there are multiple jobs that should pay more but they know some people can't do the same robotic job every day and will need to do something different.
    someone with a college degree can come in on day one and become a manager. even though they might have a degree that has nothing to do with leadership. also who wants to be a manager when you have to work 60+ hour weeks and sometimes 70+ during 'peak'? on salary pay meaning you don't get paid overtime. while everyone else isn't allowed to work over 60 hours or six days a week. makes you wonder. although the team leaders, (we call them PA's.) work roughly the same hours as the managers but get overtime. even though they aren't supposed to work over 60 hours.

2: at my sight they are about to make us put our phones in lockers to help mitigate phone usage while people work. this does make some sense in the case of some employees but some people have said that they have family that may need to be in contact with them through their phone for health reasons. Amazon may make an exception for these people but ultimately I doubt it. also there are thousands of people in the building at once and if there's a fire what do you think is going to happen?

(side story. my mom drove by to drop something off at work and security wouldn't even let her in to go to the bathroom.) (another time there was a fire in a compactor or some machine that's on the side of the building meaning that it's on the inside and outside. there's a rumor that they weren't even going to evacuate the whole plant. just part of it. even if it's just smoke that's a safety hazard. AND AMAZON IS ALL ABOUT SAFETY.

3: my site just decided to stop accepting doctor's excuses. (apparently it's always been an Amazon policy?) I started getting migraines during 'peak' a time where we work 55+ hours. it's good money but got stressful after a while. Peak usually lasts a month or two. possibly longer if amazon wants.

in the end Amazon has some great benefits and if you're there part time while going through college you should be okay. but don't work there full time if you can help it. unless you love what you're doing. there are hundreds of lvl1 employee's and losing one of them in the war for another buck is no skin off amazon's back. just go become an entrepreneur in a third world country or something.
‚úå

comment: I had a toxic coworker who embarrassed me. Let's call him Knox. Knox was dating my cousin, and he ended up cheating on her. I told her and she dumped Knox, who, long story short, found out it was me. He was so mad, he revealed something about me at work. I live in an apartment complex that's mostly for the elderly but allows disabled residents. I'm in because of my learning disability. Knox's grandma lives there and I ran into him and his family in the hall. Knox must've concluded I was living in a senior citizen place because of my disability, because he announced the fact at work. He yelled out, "John lives at [Apartment Complex]. He's 29 and lives in a complex for old people because he has a disability. Isn't that sad or what?" And then he looked at me and said, "It's really pathetic and lame, dude." Now, of course, my coworkers scolded him for revealing something that wasn't any of his or their business. They even reported him and he isn't working with us anymore. Still, I wonder if my coworkers _do_ think I'm Iame and pathetic. I mean, they didn't say I _wasn't_ those things. They didn't say I was _more than_ my disability. They didn't say my residential situation _wasn't_ anything to be ashamed of. They only told Knox he was being a jerk. That doesn't mean they don't secretly look down on me. I remember when I stood up for a classmate with dysIexia and said he was still smart and full of potential. I defended _and_ honored him at the same time. My coworkers only did the former, which leaves in room for the possibility that they think I'm a joke.
label: Negative
