comment: I have survived a toxic environment at a seasonal job I worked at. My coworkers bullied me and were dismissive and rude. Instead of advocating for myself or going for help, documenting, or anything like that, I said nothing and I was also emotionally reactive - which made things worse. I got complained about a lot, I felt isolated, unsupported, and lonely. I felt like no one appreciated or cared about me. Most of the leadership were rude to me, most of my coworkers didn't want to be around me and they gosspied about me, etc. I even got written up after a big mistake and while I do deserve the write up for the mistake, there were several other things on there that were unfair and untrue. Saying I was "agressive", "dismissive", etc. I was deeply hurt and I luckily wrote a paper addressing it, all of the points. I also made clear which points I deserved and which I didn't, and said some things what people did to me, etc. But I made sure I wrote it in a way where I am both protecting myself and the company. My boss actually felt bad for me.. but the situation still hurt me. Before the paper, they still wanted me to listen to my teammates. So I did  I did everything to make sure I didn't get in any more trouble, and I was a doormat to my teammates. At the end of the summer, people said I have grown so much? How?? How did I grow when all I did was shove myself down so people could not complain qbout me not wanting them to walk all over me???

comment:
You been there for 1 months bro. You don‚Äôt know enough to judge that ‚Äúon-call‚Äù is bad. 

First off, it‚Äôs team-dependent. Some teams rarely have anything for on-call perhaps because it‚Äôs mostly research-focused or some other reason.

On-call just means you‚Äôre working on tickets during work hours and not ‚Äúsprint work‚Äù. And after hours, yo have a pager and you get paged when an alarm goes off because one of your team‚Äôs app is F‚Äùing up.  If you understand how everything works; you can fix that issue or better yet, identify the bug and patch it so it doesn‚Äôt alarm again for example.

Having software engineers as on-call is an incentive for teams to code their apps properly without bugs so it rarely fails and so it doesn‚Äôt page them in the middle of the night
label: Negative

comment: I'm science manger at Amazon,  we have been forced to fire people to meet >6%. These number was not the percentage of putting people to focus, it's the number to let people go, e.g., I need to fire at least one people out of 10 people at my team every two quarters or even one quarter if there is new instruction from "leaders". There is very little which I can do. We also need to rank the team members performance every month to decide who will be put to focus. When something bad happen, the senior leadership willl definitely find one lower level manage or engineer to take the blame. The culture is just so toxic. Thinking about twice before you joined the company.  I also plan to record one video related with this when I quit.
label: Negative

comment: I work at Amazon, but not in the US. The culture here is really good barring all the issues that are occurring because of the state of the industry. The oncall in my country is only during the work day, so you're not expected to dial in to a call at 2am like a lot of other teams overseas. I agree that a lot of manual work exists, but I found success in automating a lot of it and it was one of the things that led to a promotion within about a year for me. The issue is that the only 2 big tech companies we have here are Google and Amazon, and Google will have maybe 2-3 open mid level engineering positions over the entire year, to work on managing legacy software rather than shipping new stuff.
label: Positive

comment:
Currently working at amazon. I work Front half night shift, Sunday - Wednesday, 6PM - 4:30AM. I lucked out- Durning training I got assigned to floor 1, that's ship dock and pack, two decent process paths- I got put into ship. Ship is great because plenty of those tasks aren't tracked at all, and the bosses down there are actually pretty chill and respectful *most* of the time. Drama is low, bathroom breaks are plenty, and you can pretty much avoid most of the hassle by being respectful, competent and not abusing the trust you get. These traits could be unique to my building- It's rather new, having only opened last year, but being in ship dock has actually been one of the more satisfying job experiences I've had. You're still just a number to them, still only getting moderately decent pay, and you still sometimes get work tracked- but you're almost never going to be fired for working too slow or having time off task if you show a baseline level of capability here. 

Me- I'm an ultra special case, I'm a dedicated Cart Builder- That means I unfold "Go-Carts," these big 7~ish foot tall rectangular metal and plastic carts, with caster wheels and double dutch-style doors- each a few hundred pounds-ish and come folded up into an L shape with usually around 128 of them nested into a single trailer. All I do all day, almost every day, is put my stuff away, put on my PPE, and just build carts all day. I spend hours on end inside a trailer just spitting carts out while other workers come and take them- I'm not tracked, I'm not monitored, the cameras usually can't see me on account of the massive wall of carts I typically produce after a few minutes- It's kinda heavenly for someone who enjoys physical work and likes a little independence. Brutal on your body but the freedom is awesome since every time I clear a trailer, my bosses usually go "Hey, nice work, why don't you take a quick five minute break" and on a good day I can score six or so breaks- enough to rest up, get snacks, and avoid overworking myself most of the time. 

Not exactly a cushy job- but there's ways to score a tolerable amount of comfort in amazon. And it can be an amazing place to go if you need a job that will keep you more physically active- I don't even go to the gym and since working here for 4 months I've lost ten pounds and my six pack is coming back, so there's that too.

For sure though- working any of the other process paths is hell, don't do it- don't listen to anyone who says "You know, getting cross-trained into pick/stow/sort is a great way to-" tell them to shut up and that you want to go into pack or ship and never let them train you for anything else. They cannot FORCE you to be trained in anything you don't want to- but once you're trained, they CAN force you to go back there- so be wary. Also don't let your Unpaid time off slip below zero- idk why this is so common but it's the number one way I hear about people getting fired from ship. You get voluntary days off, just grift for those and always keep a day of time off in case of emergencies.

Primary downside? People online get to call you corpo scum and you can't argue with them about it.
label: Positive

comment:
Well, I have lupus and hemolytic anemia, but I have been working at Amazon for two years. 

I work at a delivery station. My favorite job is unloading. I also often work as a water spider, a Non-Con unloader and sorter, a stower, and diverter. But, I also do inducting, problem solving, and straightening. Of course, I do picking, traffic control, and carts. 

I enjoy the job. I am good at it. My only complaint is that job rotation wasn't done fairly. 

Since I am an efficient and fast worker, I was given harder work regularly. I like that, because it makes it seem as though my day goes by more quickly. 

However, during times when I have severe lupus flare-ups, or I am going through an anemia pain crisis, I don't want to sort Non-Cons, or go out side in below zero temperature for 3 1/2 hours, while cute, younger women get to simply stand at a table and induct or push. 

After presenting this complaint to management about five times, nothing was done about it. So finally, I threatened to quit if I wasn't put in a rotation where I occasionally got the easier jobs too (like when I am extremely sick). They realized I wasn't bluffing. Ever since then (about 2 1/2 months ago) I get to induct and do problem solved too, instead of sorting and unloading Non-Cons all day, and going outside in below zero temperatures three or four times a week.
label: Negative

comment:
I've worked at amazon for 6 years. 5 of those years were as a tier 1 associate, across  3 departments, 2 buildings and rotated over 30 managers due to normal manager rotation (Managers rotate very frequently here). Never once have I gotten in trouble for time off task, and I've definitely gone to the bathroom as needed, filled my water bottle as needed, etc. Time off task won't show unless you've been idle for over 50-60 minutes (don't know the exact amount).

There are definitely bad managers, and it's definitely a stressful place, both mentally and physically. It is not a place to dedicate your life to. It's a place to come, get paid, and see where else you want to go. They give great starting pay for completely unskilled labor and offer great career opportunities, including fully paid college, so it works out perfectly if you're trying to do just that. But if you can go somewhere where you get paid better, if you have that possibility, there is no reason not to go for that.

If you're unskilled and have no immediate opportunities, amazon won't even interview you and you get paid almost $20 as a base. Just expect that you will be working. And you can go to the bathroom! If a manager tells you the opposite, raise it one level, or go to HR. As long as you're doing your job and didn't take 70 minutes watching a movie on the bathroom, there's nothing that they can do.
label: Positive

I think some people just not made for warehouse jobs and I can see that a lot. The thing I see more is a lot of young guys getting caught up chasing behind these young females.

comment:
Here's the thing. Treat these jobs as a gig, not a career. I worked at Procter and Gamble for a winter season, and I took every single piece of overtime they would give me. I was banking around 1200-1300 a week after taxes (which for the state and city I was in was BANK). I stayed there for a couple months with my head down and ended up walking away with several thousand dollars in savings, got my truck fixed up, had a good christmas with my family, bought a couple personal toys and then moved to a new state and started my own thing.

There were people in there who looked like they were 1 day away from jumping off the roof but they weren't seeking other work, they had no exit strategy, they took every day off they possibly could, would leave everytime there were too many people on shift etc. 

There's no denying that it sucked and the people for the most part were awful. I come from the construction world too, so all the rules and brown nosing were totally new to me. But I never let anyone with a bad attitude or who was on a power trip effect me. Just nod and so yes sir/mam please and thank you. 

If you're smart about it and willing to just concede that trading a couple months of your time is going to make you a good amount of money, these types of bean counter jobs can really be a means to an end if you play the game and have some mental fortitude.

That being said, I dont recommend it to everyone lmao.
label: Positive

They got a new warehouse, why don't you go apply?" How about they open the news and read about it?

comment: Same applies for Costco. Sure, you can go to the bathroom but get permission first. You have to clock out for lunch‚Ä¶which is a maximum of 30 minutes. If you take 31 minutes or longer, you get warned. Three warnings, you get written up. During your first 90 day trial period, you cannot take more than two days off in a row. You have no single supervisor telling you what to do. The person you are paired with tells you what to do and how to do it. They all have different ways of doing things. If you say, I was told by ‚ÄúJim‚Äù to do it this way, the reply is always ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not Jim.‚Äù It is a bully culture. There aren‚Äôt documented procedures or training for many regular tasks. I quit and promoted myself back to being a Costco member.

You had 30 minutes for lunch and if you took too many bathroom brakes I was to counsel them. In addition, it was my job to fire people based on a supervisor‚Äôs documentation. The pay was awesome but my higher self thought these employees have to be stressed out their minds! I‚Äôm going to fire them and they return gunning for me?? Halfway through the interview I politely told him I didn‚Äôt want to waste his time or mine because I could never see myself working for such an authoritarian company that abuses its employees in that manner and walk my happy out and went home.

comment:
'sup Cyberpunks? For a progressive read on themes like the fascist future Bezoz is working on please check out my new sci fi fantasy novel 'The Music Of The Spheres' by David Dangerfield' .  Themes include Australian indigenous culture, music, fashion, politics, ecological disaster, an harmonic pandemic, mythology and metaphysics... Paperback and economical eBook (instant entertainment for enduring a lockdown) now available worldwide online and in-store. At just over 100 pages it is designed to be a quick but mind bending read featuring surreal and poetic layers describing music and dance, as well as song lyrics. Published with Austen MaCauley of London.

Story synopsis: The world of the not-too distant future is plagued with ecological disaster, economic collapse and ruled by a tyrannical corporation called Omni. A twelve year old Afghan named Orpheus, cast among millions of ecological and political victims within a mass detention center in central Australia, can bend reality with their singing voice... Careful to evade Omni's brutal oppression and obsessive control over emerging new dimensional possibilities known as the 'The Spheres', Orpheus teaches their gifts there to a growing counter culture of 'Orphics'. With the help of a blind Australian indigenous elder named Yunuringa and the arrival of the comet causing the dimensional anomalies, prophesied to be an ancient artificial intelligence arc known as The Argus, Orpheus leads the Orphics at mass Corroboree's in The Spheres... With collective voice, they heal the sick, empower the poor and mend the Earth's ecology... Evolving the hearts and minds of all who can hear... The Music of the Spheres..

About the Author : Whilst working a variety of day jobs in Melbourne, Australia David Dangerfield's consuming passion has been music, composing, performing and recording a considerable trove of instrumental music over many years. From grunge, avant rock, electronic, abstract, ambient and sound scapes to performing and recording soundtracks for short film, dance, theater, arts festival pieces and digital media. To hear new and archive instrumental music by the author please search ‚ÄòDavid Dangerfield‚Äô at @t . David has also been an announcer and music programmer for commercial and public radio, DJ‚Äôed in bars and clubs and consulted to Olympians on music for sports freestyles, amongst many other musical adventures... The culmination of his extensive arts and communication industry experience is his magnum opus, The Music Of The Spheres: an epic seven part musical myth cycle, the first installment of which is this volume-The Songlines Of Orpheus.

comment: People want their stuff when they order online they usually do not think about how they get their items they just want them now and fast plus not damaged. I've worked at Walmart fulfillment, target doing fulfillment &  Amazon which each one is different now I left them all due to the companies greed not quality nor for the customer. I see Target losing a lot of online customers & money because when I picked the items most of them are not where they should be due to the fact customers place them elsewhere in the store so it is not at the location. I see why it is best to have a center where customers do not shop to get to the product & know it should hopefully be there. Most of these warehouses have dates of items that have expired and are still stowed. At Amazon people get write ups for not being productive when it is impossible to stow items because it is overfilled. Amazon seems to be a storage for items no one buys they make money monthly from people who sale through Amazon those items no one wants nor buys so the bins are too full to add anything. People work at these places because they want to be there those who do not, leave to find work elsewhere. Hopefully people know they should not be forced to work in a job they do not want to work at most of the workers I see do not really work they walk around and talk. They get their numbers because they take smaller items from others and that is how they keep their job and low rates while others work hard and get written up than fired . These companies will always stay in business because people will work there nothing anyone can do unless people stop supporting these type of businesses which will never happen because people want stuff. I have a business to help people start college by helping them apply to school & get them financial aid many have started their own companies & now have better careers. These jobs are to help you get a start while going to school or help pay bills but mostly these types of warehouse jobs are temp & people are replaceable to these companies which is why it is best to start your own business and get paid doing something you enjoy.

comment:
1) Some of these issues are not Amazon-specific issues, but warehouse company issues. As in it's not just Amazon doing it, so don't get it twisted, you go anywhere else that has a warehouse, expect the same stuff.  It does seem like every person in HR or Learning that I talk to, tells me something different than the previous person did. But I suspect that's true of any company. Also their app can be very confusing, but again, I assume that's not only an Amazon problem, although since it IS a problem, they really should have people who deal with that specifically.

2) I've heard some horror stories, and I won't deny some are/were true, but I think a lot of it depends on the location you're working at. So far I haven't run into too much trouble, but I've only been there for a couple of months. And I want to stress, I came from another warehouse company that had longer shifts, so a shorter shift with more break time was a breath of fresh air, even for lower pay. One thing I can say is my location isn't as fixated on scan rate as my last job was. Possibly to their detriment, as we constantly have people clocking in, then hiding in the parking lot or worse, the restrooms, which prevents people who are actually working from doing what they need to do. As for managers, here you also don't really know who yours is, because you don't really belong to one department, they send us all over the warehouse, so in a week you may interact with five or six different managers. But as a plus, if there's a manager you don't like, odds are you won't have to deal with them every single day. They do claim you can request to work in a specific part of the building, but that seems to be most effective for people with accommodations, and even then they can't avoid it all of the time.

And as for the asthma, he definitely should have gotten some sort of accommodation for that. I can tell you there are people at my location who are deaf, or have autism, or have bad legs, and they still have jobs somehow. And that is despite some of them doing far less work. And yes I know how that sounds, but when you are tired and doing your best to stay on task, and you look up and see the autistic guy walking by humming to himself for a whole hour without doing any work, all I can think is, "Must be nice." Maybe you have to stay on them about it, and report it if they don't adjust your tasks enough. I do recall a pregnant woman had a similar issue, not sure what she did about it. But on that note, the only advice I can give is not really helpful: I would not choose to work in a warehouse if I were pregnant or planned to be, or if I had any sort of medical condition that prevented me from moving with speed or regularity, because that's exactly what they want from you. To me it kinda seems like applying to work at a restaurant but you know the smell of food makes you ill, why would you do that to yourself?

comment:
I needed to see this video. ‚ô• The feeling you're describing, that paralysis and complete inability to focus, I was there in 2022. Only, I didn't trust myself to find another well paying job, so instead of quitting after 2 months, I quit after 2 years, when I could absolutely not hold on any longer. I didn't turn to drugs, but I was a zombie for the rest of 2024. Basically all I did for months on end was let my nervous system decompress.¬†

Then in 2025, I focused on my physical health and building better regulation. I did a ton of work on myself, looking back I find the person I used to be almost completely unrecognizable, but I still avoided programming. Too many negative emotions associated with it, combined with the fear of falling behind in a shitty job market. There was a knot in my stomach every time I opened my laptop.¬†

Now it's 2026, and I'm slowly getting back into the habit of learning. I'm focusing on consistency over high pressure. I'm hoping to get back on the horse, this time with firmer hands on the reigns. Cheers!

comment: What is wrong with people... I was dropped into a high stress, high reward environment, as an IT guy, it was sink or swim... No one held my hand, no one give me the time of day... 30 years later... I was at the time in the top tier IT engineering, of a Fortune 10 financial firm, creating, yes creating their virtualization strategy that they still are improving on to this day, given I retired about 7 years go.  I started at the very bottom in the company and ended at the very to evaluating emerging technologies the firm wanted evaluated, real cutting edge only under NDA agreement concepts.  Never made crazy money, but good money, I never made more than 140 as base salary.  But was always was consistently employed, and yes I got some nice bonuses, and created a few patents, which the company owns, but I got credit for.  So I retired well, and life well, but never rich.  That said,  I really struggle with these kids that just cannot seem to handle any pressure or any expectation of achievement.  Sorry, but all I hear is someone that is playing the victim.  Maybe you should not use drugs, are you kidding me?  Maybe you should just learn to deal with stress.  The IT world is completely results driven... you selected the wrong industry?  If you were next to me, in the field or office... of course I would help you, and more, I helped many peers, because I learned from them as well.  I never once asked myself if I was in the wrong position... all I ever asked myself was... OK... how can I improve, especially when I made mistakes, which at times I did.  But I always got back to it, failure was never an option, never a realistic result, improve, overcome.  Yes, there were many 60-70 weeks... many times I worked 36 hour days... that is what it takes at times.  Now I see and hear many junior IT  people crying and screaming on tik-tok because they had to work 4 or 6 hours straight?  Or they are on call and don't have time to eat or sleep?  What are you, a kid, real life folks.  Geez try 24 or 36 hours with only 15 minute breaks...  So it was hard, sure it was insane at times... it was the job, and you did it.... no excuses, no dumb decisions like drugs, just pride in doing a job right, because it was... oh I don't know... right to do the job they are paying you to do.  I guess few will read this because it is too long of a reply... your loss.  But if you did read this entire comment... just maybe you are like me... willing to do that extra step, committed to constant improvement... Bravo if that is the case.
label: Positive

comment: Fellow Amazonian here (corporate). I'm resigning tomorrow - this video helped me make peace with the decision (though the decision-making process was months long). It's both scary and exciting, but everything you mentioned here resonated so much with me! It's time, after nearly 8 years. I'm 30, single, living within my means with financial comfort, and ready to move into a season of life where I can pursue self-employment and freedom - ultimately with the goal of being a work-from-home, stay-at-home mom long-term (if God blesses me with a husband and kids someday) or simply just being a single woman with freedom! That path isn't necessarily celebrated in society, but after seeing what society/the world has to offer, not all that glitters is gold. I've checked the box for "hanging in there" and "paying my dues" in a corporate job at Amazon, and it's time for a new season and new way of life. Thank you for the encouraging and affirming video! Spot on.

I am also close to quitting my job/company after close to 30 years, I work for a huge corporate company and given my everything for the "3% per year" annual increase and many years, this was barely enough to cover inflation.  We were not even lucky to get any equity plans as it is a private company.  I have finally realised this is not a good situation for me and my family.

comment:
So, if you want work in an environment of competitive, career obsessed psychopaths, Amazon‚Äôs the place for you.

I was an Amazon customer since it was an online bookstore in Seattle. I cancelled my Prime membership in January when they closed all their operations in Quebec, claiming it was a business decision. Coincidentally, this happened around the time staff at a distribution centre decided to unionise, something Amazon üòäüòäcouldn‚Äôt fight because of the province‚Äôs strong labour laws. They‚Äôre expanding their warehouse capacity in cities on the other side of the provincial border and will be fulfilling deliveries from there. Since then, I‚Äôm seeing fewer and fewer Amazon boxes on local doorsteps.

I‚Äôve always been aware of Amazon‚Äôs anti-union stance but ignored it until it affected my community. I‚Äôm also opposed to their mandatory return to office policy. It doesn‚Äôt make sense in places with poor public transportation, long commutes and bitterly cold weather. It discriminates against parents with young children and the disabled.

comment:
I used to work for amazon as an SDE. You're right that if you're on the right team/org/senior manager/product it can be a good place to work, but from the outside when you apply you don't have any of that information. And even if you do end up on a good team it can all change at a moment's notice with a reorg.

It makes sense that they're using leadership principles to put people on PIPs though. It means you could PIP people without hard data. The LPs were frequently weaponized so managers could get their way but this means it's possible to get rid of individuals for vague reasons.
label: Positive

comment:
Accepting an offer from Amazon was the worst decision of my life. After 2 years I was burnt out and my mental health hit rock bottom with suicide thoughts. My job was, and still is, the envy of many young software engineers (result of Amazon's heavy marketing invstment targeted at them), yet in reality I can't think of anything worse that can happen to someone than when something makes you want to end life yourself. How did I get there? In short, Amazon's high bar mentality (nothing you ever do is good enough), competition between colleagues, constant lies by management, moving goal posts, etc.. It's hard to stay mentally sane when you work all the time, you achive 4x more than any regular employee in a similar role at a different company, you know you are world-class level, yet you're told you're trash all the time and you get put on PIP. One year after I left I still have anxiety attacks and I can't say I am well, I'm afraid I'll never be as I was before Amazon. It was truly traumatic.

I wouldn't recommend anyone to join Amazon. If you are good enought to thrive at Amazon you will do better by founding a business, or you will inevitably rise fast in your career in other places. Don't be stupid like I was.
label: Negative

comment: My journey at Amazon has been quite unique. I got poached from my temp agency early and I have been going strong about to be 2 years in. I also was able to vertically transfer 2 times without interviews and have been an asset and every team. I was literally hand picked to improve a whole team. Idk how my experience is so unique to others. My first forte I was rated the best. Idk man I think it‚Äôs a game and I play it well. And a top tier performer.

comment:
I was part of the Initial PIP layoffs, working as a tech lead. They're smokescreen. I have friends still at the company who give me tea all the time. My team had multiple deployments, worked well beyond labor laws, our "performance" was the best amongst our particular region. My mistake? The OT and pay being well above most of my peers. My pip was totally unreasonable given the amount of overnight migrations and 20+ projects we worked on. My performance, ironically, was improving as I had began to automate a lot of my admin work just as ChatGPT blew up in popularity. Got my PIP, the whole team thought it was bs, since I was outperforming and had hands on most of our projects. 

Yeah. It's all an excuse to cut costs with the upcoming economic downturn. Do not believe that AI is the primary causer. It's a symptom, not the source of their issues. They've been having issues for a while.

comment:
In a previous org, I had a boss put me on a PIP. This was completely unsubstantiated and, I suspect, motivated by the fact that she just didn‚Äôt like me. Fortunately, my org had a program called "360 evaluation" that sent out surveys to colleagues throughout the org (executive stakeholders, team members, clients, etc). I escalated to her boss and insisted that I get a 360 eval because my boss had no concrete examples of why I was on PIP (mainly platitudes of her feelings of how I was performing). As an aside, I was open to specific feedback on how I could improve, but she didn‚Äôt have any to give me. No way to get off PIP if it is just vibes. When the eval came back, I ranked extremely highly from all levels, including getting praise from senior executives. That got my PIP removed immediately. She left my team to work on another team shortly thereafter.

Bottom line, if you are getting PIP'd and you think it is unsubstantiated,  gather data and fight back!
label: Positive

comment: I was a USPS rural deliveryman. Average packages/day on my route was 150-200, but you also have to deliver the mail (500+stops), and pick-up packages, all the while you are monitored and timed as anything that takes you 5 minutes you are flagged to the postmaster who can then pull you into the office to have a "talk" if he/she wants. Too many flags of this kind upper management also know and will hard pressure the postmaster to give the offender a spanking. This is when you do need the union to protect you. During Holidays and Amazon sales, your package load will increase around 50%/day. The covid years were even worse as 200-300 packages a day was normal and as there were always people out with covid, you finish your route and help on another. 11+hours a day 6 days a week was the normal. Some of us would also work a half day on Sunday (optional work). You work at these jobs, but at least at the USPS you can make decent money and if full time you have excellent benefits (pension, top healthcare, ect). it's laughable when people b*tch about a stamp going up a couple of pennies, as for most people this is hardly more than a dollar a year increase, because they think you sit on your bum and get overpaid. Also, if you use Amazon, don't share your fake empathy for the drivers. If you would buy local Amazon wouldn't have the stranglehold they do.
label: Positive

comment:
In my experience, working at Amazon‚Äôs distribution center was one of the easiest jobs I‚Äôve ever had. My position was simply scanning packages all night, and a lot of the negative claims you hear‚Äîlike ‚Äúyou can‚Äôt take breaks‚Äù or ‚Äúthey overwork you‚Äù‚Äîjust weren‚Äôt true for me. They offered plenty of benefits, not only for employees but also for their families. Schedules were flexible, there was PTO and VTO, and you could pick up extra shifts if you wanted to earn more.

Yes, the work can be a bit tiresome and repetitive, especially during peak season (I worked through COVID), but it was far from unbearable. The pay was also better than what I earned at other jobs afterward. Maybe I was lucky with my location, but my experience was positive overall.

If you‚Äôre curious, I‚Äôd say give Amazon a try‚Äîthey‚Äôre always hiring, and you might be surprised. I worked third shift, kept to myself, and found the environment manageable and even pleasant at times.
label: Positive

comment:
Well, this is a strange phenomenon in the world where a labourer sweating it out in the sun gets only some wages and one meal, while someone sitting in Air conditioned offices makes slightly more doing mentally challenging work.  The per day earning would be almost the same for an entry level executive and a labourer. (Provided labourers are getting high wages like those in Kerala)..

However, let me share my personal experience of working in Amazon DC as a Content Reviewer in VSE (Video Shopping Experience). If you have been under impression that there is only software development happening in these companies then better modify the perception.

As an entry level executive, you have to be a girl, or a cunning guy who can smoke with your mentor during breaks to get progress. At least, you are not supposed to find flaws in the system. Some people who joined at the initial launch of the operations in India, had a headstart and even though having pathetic skills in verbal and written communication, they became the big politicians in the office. As a teetotaller, non smoker and having a better skill in communicative English, my fellow senior colleagues and managers felt threatened and played politics to keep my productivity lower. While the experienced fellows used unethical tricks to jack up their productivity with support of manager, I was in constant monitoring for not using the same tricks. 

Even though I worked my ass off everyday, from start to end of the shift, my productivity was short of 90-95 percent. I never used the recreation room for even a second in my 9 months of stay. I still found it a good job at Amazon as the shift timings were so comfortable and I had two weekly holidays on Saturday, Sunday. And of course the office facilities and food courts are world class. 

Recognition was missing for me. Even for non core work efforts too. I recall creating an RandR (Rewards and Recognition) graphic poster for an office competition but my suggestion only completed after the announcement of the winners. Everybody was congratulating me for the innovative idea. But that effort also got no official recognition.

Maybe I was just unlucky to get a bad team. Anyways, I could not stay longer as I had to resign abruptly when my ageing father fell sick and I had to return home to continue in his retail business.

It's not meant to scare anyone. Maybe it was my age factor also that prevented my team to have a better relationship with me as I was slightly older in age to my senior colleagues and managers. Anyways, after realising so many other people expressing their nightmares in various private and Government jobs, I feel maybe it's best to leave things to destiny.
label: Positive

comment:
I have worked in a BPO, a startup, a small enterprise, a huge IT MNC and Amazon. Amazon is the worst organisation to work for. They mess up your life and mental health like no joke. The ones who are saying that Amazon is a good company, are lying through the teeth. Its the biggest farce there is. Nobody gives a f**k about work, process, efficiency, continuous improvement, performance, better management, work life balance or anything remotely relatable. All they care about is PIP, screen tracker, who is coming to office on which day at what time, who is spending how much time for lunch, etc.
I am currently working for an IT giant, and they provide AWS certification for free. But drumroll... Amazon charges their own employees for AWS certification, followed by a bond.
I worked with 2 great managers in Amazon, but it physically hurts to see their managerial potential dead by the neck. They are literally, I mean literally, forced to put people on PIP for reasons so silly, you will want to kill yourself. Oh and the ones talking about the great pay? Boy you have absolutely no idea what scam they are running in the CTC. Oh and by the way, the managers who tried to do the right thing by refusing to adhere to such nincompoop policies, have been thrown out or are currently serving PIP. I can go on and on and on.
So to the people who say they "love working for Amazon" - you skill-less, spineless, worthless losers are going to die serving the scam behemoth, because you are too useless to get any job outside. I wish you die the dog's death, because it will be better than the dog life you are living right now.

I used to work at an Amazon sortation center.
  During training to be a PIT driver, we were given a list of "dos and don'ts" for operating PIT.

  On the warehouse floor, however, the AMs told us to ignore the "dos and don'ts" and just "do as told."

At one point, I tried to report a PIT driver for trying to play "chicken" with other operators. And the managers told me not to worry about it and get back to work..

 They eventually stopped doing PIT in favor of pallet Jack's due to all the collisions between PIT.

Have you ever seen a 1,000lb battery split open? I have. It's not pretty.

comment: I'm currently with Amazon. Working within the Air Network for just a little over a year now, and it has honestly been a very negative experience. Unfortunately, management here is not leadership based. I came from an FC where communication and the requirements for standard of work was more flowing. Things just made a little more sense. But most importantly, The Team! The Team I was directly working with is what made the difference. Unfortunately, I am now in a position where I am being almost given no choice but to have to leave. My recommendation to anyone is that anywhere you go, if the environment and culture isn't right within the site or just in general (meaning company wide), then you will surely pay with 'all your being', having to endure mental stress, constant discomfort and continuous discouragement. Amazon prides itself in being a leader and innovator, but it truly doesn't do a great job in vetting or continuously checking how sites are ran from a cultural and moral standpoint. And that my friends is a huge issue. These 14 to 16 leadership principles the company prides itself as living or running by is not what it seems, unfortunately.

comment:
1. **Amazon's Four-Year Cliff**: The speaker left Amazon due to the "four-year cliff," where stock compensation heavily diminishes after the initial four years.
2. **Compensation Breakdown**: At Amazon, compensation includes base salary and "bridge cash" in the first two years, with stock vesting as follows: 5% in year one, 15% in year two, and 40% each in years three and four.
3. **Bridge Cash Removal**: By year three, bridge cash ends, and employees rely solely on stock, which fluctuates with market performance.
4. **Stock Market Risk**: This structure can be a gamble if Amazon's stock price declines, impacting total compensation in the later years.
5. **Promotion Disadvantages**: Promotions increase workload with minimal pay increase, and newly promoted employees are placed at the lower end of their new pay band.
6. **External Opportunities**: The speaker notes that similar roles outside Amazon offer higher pay, bonuses, and new stock options, often with fewer responsibilities.
7. **Talent Retention Strategy**: Amazon‚Äôs compensation structure discourages long-term retention to avoid employee complacency, pushing employees to seek external opportunities after four years.
8. **Importance of Market Value**: The speaker emphasizes regularly assessing one's value in the job market to ensure career and financial growth.
9. **Personal Decision**: Leaving Amazon was beneficial for career development and financial reasons, as it allowed the speaker to take on new challenges and responsibilities.
10. **Conclusion**: The speaker finds fulfillment in new learning experiences, contrasting with the routine, automated nature of tasks in long-term roles.

I decided to order something (GPU) for the first time with Amazon. Made an account and ordered a second hand GPU i needed for my work. Next day it came in a cardboard box that was falling apart. The GPU box was missing a lid, the GPU looked fine but did not turn on. So i tried to return it the next day after i left a negative review on this product with a photo of how it got delivered, a few hours afters i left this review my account got suspended and the review removed.

After some trouble i got emailed a return code that was not accepted by UPC or UPS, so after visiting 5 shops that would return my package but refused the code i called Amazon again, they send me a wrong code and now send me the correct code. It worked with the first place i delivered it to. Now a month later my order account is still suspended and my money is not returned while they accepted my return package and agreed for a refund(i repaired the carboard box with allot of tape.) This is a horrible first experience with Amazon and has made not want to order anything online anymore.

comment:
My son went from working hard on a hay farm to being a package driver for Amazon for one dollar more an hour. He loved it at first but that love quickly wore off. As he kept making his delivery time goals each week, they kept pushing him more and more without any bonuses. It was never good enough. He was working 12-hour shifts. He was exhausted,  going up flights upstairs carrying packages daily. 
The better he was, the more they worked him until he completely gave out. Once he tripped on a step and he was terrified to tell management so he wouldn't get yelled at n get a mark against him or get fired. I cleaned his elbow and super glued his elbow skin together and put butterfly stitches on it send sent him back to work. 
A year later, after 2 years of no raises, tighter goals to meet, no recognition for safety, and reaching his goals, he gave up n quit. 

This Statement is from KM on an Amazon Prime Commercial.
5 months ago

comment: This idea of constantly changing and moving on is great and sounds fitting in some of these tech jobs but not necessary stable for the general working family. Someone with a few kids likely wants something that can cover their family for a while versus having to constantly switch things up every 4 years. And it's also easier when you're still younger; obviously that's what companies like Amazon are betting on.
label: Positive

comment: I'm also ex-Amazon. Was there for just under 6 years. One point of perspective on the 4-year cliff, my understanding is that it's set up that way not only to stave off complacency, but it's in essence an "up or out" dynamic. Meaning, you're expected to either move up or move on. That's why the pay levels are structured to fall at the 4-year mark. But at review time, you can be rewarded with additional RSU's that enable you to maintain your comp level as an IC (individual contributor) even if you're not pursuing a promotion (which is what happened for me and why I stayed past the 4 years despite not moving to L7), which can be a difficult hill to climb.

comment: Another important thing you didn't mention: 15% stock growth rule. At year 3, amazn will give you new stocks for year 5 and 6, say 100K for each year. Instead of giving you 100K worth of stocks, amzn actually gives you: 100K/1.15 = 86.95K worth of stocks for year 5 and 100K/1.15 /1.15= 75.6K for year 6. So, what happens if stock price increase more than 15%? you should be thankful since you make more than 100K at year 5 or 6. did management ask you to be grateful (e.g you are making more than we want to give you). Yes; did hard work pay off? Absolutely No.

comment:
Several points to add to what Dave said:
1. the document that managers write to promote someone is called a promo doc, it's not the same as a 6-pager doc. but there's a template to structure the doc, and length limit (If I recall should be ~3-4 pages)
2. bar raiser is not always added to L4 interview loops (this was during  COVID era when Amazon was hiring a lot of poeple)
3. bar raiser's role is to maintain the hiring standards (thus the name bar 'raiser') and act as counter balance, as hiring manager would have natural inclination to hire the candidate (and grow their number of reports  - mentioned as the success metric for SDMs). It's more likely for SDM to be inclined and bar raiser not inclined, vs the other way round.
4. oncall - the operation load and emphasis on operational excellence varies a lot across orgs (and sometimes even across teams in an org). obviously this would be depenent on the services' impact on customer/business when an outage happen. not all teams work on tier-1 systems that could trigger SEV-1. for some teams, the highest sev they can cause is a SEV-2, and subsequently the oncall can be pretty chill.
5. good managers bringing people with them to new org - this helps bring new ideas but there are also cons. It's great when the new org's problem domain is similar to the old one, but there are also times when new management brings a lot an influx of people with senior titles but have little domain knowledge 
6. team autonomy in choosing tools they want - in practice there's a strong preference to use AWS and/or internally supported frameworks to build software. there's also 'not invented here' syndrome that makes it hard to use external products/solutions. Once in a while there are teams that do things their own way like the team that built a service in Lisp, but as Dave mentioned those often end up being scrapped and rewritten after the original engineers leave.
label: Positive

comment:
The description of how someone gets PIP‚Äôed at AMZ is a bit disingenuous. Dave says at 54:58  the description of a low rating/letting someone go is not necessarily that they are ‚Äúnot meeting expectations‚Äù but rather that they are merely the ‚Äúleast effective‚Äù team members.

But the company‚Äôs official policy, both what‚Äôs public facing and the official communications to individual employees, is that employees are PIP‚Äôed because they are ‚Äúnot meeting expectations of the role‚Äù. (I was PIP‚Äôed for the record. I was told I the ‚Äúnot meeting expectations‚Äù phrase many times).

It‚Äôs also company policy to not explicitly disclose a ‚ÄúLeast Effective‚Äù to an employee.

comment:
I was told if i wanted to keep working there I had to walk faster to the bathroom and when filling up water bottle on way back from my one break to the bathroom.  You have to start your scanner again once break is over and get it online again - that takes almost a minute to get it strapped on and actually scanning packages.  Even if you are standing there trying to get the thing working at your station - you are considered still on break until it works and you scan a package.  Your break isn‚Äôt considered over in the computer until you have scanned again.  And the thing has to be put back on your hand and arm - get the Bluetooth thing running again - that doesn‚Äôt matter - that is considered your break until the computer sees you are scanning packages.  So I was told to walk faster to have time to get the thing working again to get my break to be considered over when I can scan again - even tho I returned from breaks on time.  The scanner wasn‚Äôt operating magically as I appeared at my station - so that is considered the employees break time to get the companies equipment to work.  
It is so hot - even in winter - you have to drink water -  but just to be able to run to the bathroom and make it back without being called out for it is a big issue.  Even for women that need to go to the restroom for female things - better figure out a way to do it and keep the stuff you need on your person.  No bags allowed -  o phones allowed - you don‚Äôt know what time it is or how long you been gone.  It is impossible to succeed and be able to keep doing it.  High turn over means they are always paying starting pay rates for large percent of workers.  Very rough working conditions.  Very strenuous - which is ok - but you need water - need some damn air in hot ass building even in winter.  Now they are turning off water coolers so the water stays warm too.  Nice little bullshit thing they doing.  Everyone has been unplugged.  
I got to hand it to the people that can last there - you are tougher than I.   I will only do part time now - all my body can take without stroking out in there.  Some people can‚Äôt do the part time - feel very bad for them.  It‚Äôs brutal and you are constantly told you aren‚Äôt doing enough or you can‚Äôt pee fast enough or something.   They do lie about the wages too - I have seen those comments here as well - that is true.  I was bold face lied to about pay.  
UNION has to be better.  At least get cool water and a big fan (there are huge fans on ceiling but never turned on!!!) and a bathroom close enough to be  able to get to in decent amount of time so you don‚Äôt have to spend your break trying to get their crap equipment working again.

comment:
I'm a retired U.S. Military Combat Pilot (26 years) I support these people 100%!! My daughter was hired as a delivery driver in Texas.  They ran her ragged, their feet were basically in her neck to perform.  Here is what she told us

1.  She  started out in a smaller truck, delivering 400 packages in her shift 

2.  She  was a hustler, she would return early for a  few shifts. They offered her to upgrade to their big Mercedes truck and added 3 additional bins of crap 600++ packages.  They told her the pay was gonna jump to $27.00 never happened 

She  was getting $16 per hour and not $27

3.  The trucks were unadulterated unsafe crap that should not have been on the road there maintenance program sucks. She would have trucks with the rearview mirrors or flopping could not get them to stay in place so when she had back up it was extremely difficult she was feared as she would run into another vehicle. The windshields on a couple of the trucks had cracks in the windshield next she said the tires were worn out an extremely low tread, the brakes were horrible and to make things worse they gave her to navigate all of these locations an Apple SE iPhone with a barcode reader on the back These items were worthless and consistent they would scan packages but a time she would have to scan scan scan before she actually scanned the package and it recorded the data she did this for three weeks

Finally in the middle of her shift with 4 bins still full she turned around and drive back to the warehouse and handed them the keys and phone.

She told them " How can you with a good conscious expect us to deliver this chit in a safe manner. It's impossible.!I refuse to work under these horrible conditions and told I am officially resigning.  She  was very pleasant Az bout the whole thing. comment: I never, in all my years of working, heard the complaint that it isn‚Äôt fair to have to stand all day when that is the only way to do the job.  Factory work is tough and if one does not like it, then leave. I had a factory job for four hours where I was pressured to fold 1000 envelopes per hour and could pee only when a light was turned on.  At lunch, I asked some of the employees if they like their jobs. Most said yes because the routine and constant grind was relaxing. Others said no but they did not know how to quit. I said I didn‚Äôt like the work and suggested to all the unhappy workers to watch me and take a lesson on how to quit.  I had no money except what this job would provide, but I knew I was not going to fold another envelope.  People watched and I went back five days later to pick up my check.  I got another job.

comment:
As a Norwegian I find it odd that a company can simply refuse a union. In Norway, you only need 20% of the workers to register in a union and you can demand what is called a "tariffavtale". A "tariffavtale" is a yearly negotiated agreement with the relevant sector that sets saleries, rules, overtime, safety regulations etc.

Unions in Norway are incredibly strong, because almost all unions are gathered under one umbrella. You can say the unions are unionized

comment:
*This is the easiest economy to land a job in. As well, this economy is has the least valued US dollar. Amazon warehouse is my backup job should I lose this one.* Any disciplined ex military, athlete or police would be in management in 2 years (high conflict/ low IQ). They hire disabled people alot, too. 
*Ive been to these distribution centers. I Walked around the Facility with only the steel frame and Foundation complete in 2018 near a Washington State Airport.
 ‚ö†Ô∏è A fire that big in a 4 million sqaure foot warehouse is not a big deal. Most of those 600 employees only herd about this on telegram and snapshot over an hour later. It takes you more than 10 minutes to walk across an amazon distribution center. Holiday bathroom walking times are about 15-20 minutes with forklifts and BoxBots and seasonal crew. You will have to relieve yourself into a Gatorade bottle from November to February, nationwide. I've always been required to use the Gatorade method at every job I've had since 1994. Many blue collar (no degree requirements) need tondo this on the job site everyday. üòÖBig _ucking deal. This job is literally the easiest way to pay bills if you are not overweight and can read a phone well. You will not need to learn English to work at Amazon. They pay you a clean $100 cash daily and pay you the rest of your daily wage (40%) in a weekly Friday paycheck. 10% of your co-workers will sleep in a VW van on Amazon property and just Do Hookers & Blow 48 hours at a time. Amazon will give you a $120 Zappos shoe store gift card to get boots or saftey shoes. If you cannot afford to eat food the management will just write off warehouse food for you to eat or buy you pizza until your next weekly/Friday. This is a long standing regional "goods defferment policy" since Bezos Had Book Warehouses in Portland in the 90's. I'm a hometown guy and many of my hippy friends ate pizza hut at lunch provided from the Amazon management team perty cash fund, maybe this is 1998 or 2000. The free pizza is all they ate that day. Upon a local Areotech  headhunter calling me in 2020, Oct: what I herd then is the first warehouse  job pitch that provides immediate performance bonuses and benefits after six months. A $4,500 bonus after 90 days and a good performance review. 

‚ö†Ô∏è  üò¢ The Amazon Corporate strategy is that you will outperform the Latina Grandma working the the left of you and the achoholic Iraq war vet to your right. The Amazon HR algorithm will terminate the employment those two nice people and call them "inefficient labor assets." Amazon will receive a labor injury insurance savings and you'll be real busy but you'll earn an extra $10+ a year just by out working your co-workers ‚óá‚óá Rinse and repeat. 48 months later and now You drive a candy red Mercedes with carbon fiber brakes to the executive lot, some nice person parks it for you, you just walking around the warehouse drinking coffee and scrolling instagram pretending to observe this or that until lunchtime. Well for your lunch today...you'll eat your secretary's a55 like a watermelon. üçâ

comment:
The new H.R. Manager who is Hispanic at a manufacturing company that I work for has only hired Hispanics and African-Americans since the other Administrator retired -- I'm the only long term employee left.  I've been there for over 15 years in the Accounting Department and I'm "White".

The H.R. Manager and all of the other 'office personnel' are all relatively new.  The H.R. Manager and the newer female employees are all about the same age 30s and early 40s.  On several occasions the H.R. Manager will come into the open room that has many desks filled with the new employees who are her age and she will tell a 'deragotary' story -- which she will say at the end, "You know, it must be a WHITE THING"!  She tells the story of an experience that she's had and at the end of it she says, "Oh, yeah.  That's a WHITE THING"!   I'm the only white person in the room and it makes me feel slighted and degraded.

She has also called me into her office in a closed door meeting and tells me, "You know, you don't have a lot in common with the younger girls in the office, you've never had any kids -- so if the other girls don't seem to talk to you that much -- it's just that they're younger and they have kids."  Thus, giving me the reason as to 'why' I've been ostersized and ignored by my newer co-workers.  She actually said, "You don't speak Spanish either, so you don't really understand what they're talking about."

Isn't this discriminatory and illegal?  I find it very offensive when she tells her negative stories and then ends it with "Oh, yeah . . . that's a WHITE THING"!
label: Negative

comment: I secured a property management job through a female colleague who I had previously worked with at another company, and she got me the job. Everything was good, going out for morning coffees, etc, this work colleague turned on me after a few months.  I was singled out as a male in an all female office and HR organized the entire office to write identical accounts of why I made them feel uncomfortable in the workplace. So embarrassing. My wife and daughter had visited the office before, and everything seemed friendly, but told them things were not going well at work. I was told to go work at home by HR. My female manager is the only one who did not know this was going on, and had no idea why I was unable to work from the office, or that there was anything happening in the office (she worked in the office too!) The senior management located in another city took a hard line, and with no evidence against me, would not even tell me what allegations were made, closed ranks and refused to return my calls. I was left with no computer access to do work and was left in limbo for over a month. The company ghosted me. HR did not even contact me, and I notified them that my colleague (who got me the job) was threatening me via txt to leave the company, 'or I would never work in this town again' , and HR did nothing. I contacted my lawyer. Unfortunately, my lawyer had a conflict of interest with the company/law firm I worked for, but did not disclose this straight away. They recommended that I hand in my notice. I ended up handing in my notice, in return for a payout of 6 months salary, instead of taking the company to employment court.  I met with the branch boss about 6 months later for coffee, and she said 'it was just business, not personal'. I was so traumatized, and did not work for two years.
label: Negative

comment:
Hi there,

I was employed with Cubic Transportation System who work closely with Australian Government - Transport.

Since my joining, I was facing -

1. Gatekeeping of information, my accesses to different platforms were not getting sorted for months and I was given the vibe that it was on me.

2. Handover of equipments were delayed.

3. Constant bullying by my immediate manager.

4. Abuse sometimes got so extreme that my manager used to come to me while folding his sleeve. Yelling and shouting got kind of normalized.

5. Frequent threat to report me to HR. Although never got any clarification on what part would I be reported to!!

6. I was forced to come to the an almost empty office, 5 days a week where my manager was coming 2 days and another team member was coming once in every two weeks.

Finally, I decided to raise this issue to HR. No outcome as they felt the evidences were not enough to substantiate.


20 days later, day before yesterday I was called in for performance review. And 30 minutes long meeting lasted only 50 seconds where I was handed over the letter of termination. They made me erase all everything from the devices and submit it.


I was fired with 50 seconds of notice.

comment:
Thank you, Mr. Robertson; I have been busying myself with writing a book. I am Canadian, and I know you practice in California. Thank you for your efforts in educating a legally illiterate individual. I had been employed by the City of Ottawa for twenty-nine and a half years. I had distinguished myself as an elite operator, winning six annual bus Roadeo competitions. After twenty-one years of accident-free driving, I accepted a position in the training department as a Relief-Instructor. Aside from my workload doubling because HR failed to acknowledge an additional attrition rate of six hundred operators hired between 1974-75-76. 

Five colleagues and I were enrolled to attend a weeklong course facilitated by an outside agency, the Canadian Urban Transit Association (CUTA). January 21 - 25, 2008. 7:00 am to 4:00 pm, Monday to Friday. Unpaid homework until 1:00 am to 2:00 am with a one-hour commute to a different locale. This pace proved overly stressful for me due to how the assignments were distributed. I was assigned to convey the summary of the five previous segments facilitated by my colleagues. My assignment was the total of all the information my colleagues had previously taught. Each day was taking a more significant toll on my cognitive abilities. I succumbed to the ravages of a nervous breakdown. It was prescribed by my family physician to convalesce at home. The ailment progressed to include the trifecta of mental illnesses. Severe Depressive Disorder, a form of PTSD, Anxiety Disorder, up to and including Panic Attacks, and Bipolar Disorder.  

A far more significant effect was the loss of my family. These disorders proved too much for my spouse of thirty years. She initiated the separation and subsequent divorce. Three attempted suicides sealed my fate forever. These mood disorders have a way of diminishing my resiliency, self-esteem, and self-worth. My three children and seven grandchildren are now estranged under the tutelage of their mother/grandmother. A man's purpose in life is to find his purpose in life. 

I lost my employment via a pre-emptive constructive dismissal. No employer has the right to position its employees. In contrast, they can be held criminally liable for teaching in contravention of the Highway Traffic Act under the deception that an exculpatory agreement existed in the archives of City Hall. I attempted to secure a copy of the agreement to no avail. The Union Representatives were complicit in that they proved themselves to be inept.

I was demoted to my substantive position as a transit operator. I could not accept the term offered as the illegal maneuver persists today. There's a statute of limitation on my case. If so, I am vehemently opposed due to the ongoing unlawful practice. How can a statute have any forbearance on an issue when 1700 employees continue to execute the illegal maneuver?

Agencies and individuals who can no longer attest to having plausible deniability.
From the training department Supervisor (3) in seven years to the General Manager (2), claimed it was all water under the bridge.
Law enforcement, Chiefs of both divisions
Ministry of Transportation. No reply
The overseer of the training program, the Driver Certification Executive Officer (DCEO), responds, "We're gonna have to keep an I out for you.
Ontario Ombudsman.
 In a Unionized environment, I could not avail myself of a competent lawyer citing a conflict of interest. What do you do when inept Union Reps, to whom I had been paying dues, can justify throwing me under the bus. 
Canadian Industrial Relations Board. Denied my claim against the Union under sec. 37 Duty to fair representation. I had worked diligently to prepare my information in the manner that was said. I was told point blank that CIRB would not accept my claim because I was a week late in submitting the case. Justice be damned.     
Colleagues who would listen.
 'nough said. RHP

comment:
It doesn't make sense to skip a level despite what the company says. There's a reason for it not to be published similar to their naming conventions of facilities. Every now and then you'll find a facility's name, acronym, or nomenclature sequence # skipped somewhere. But I'll go on a tangent so that's another conversation.

About L2: it is more commonly understood to be considered Learning Ambassadors or LAs...rather unofficially. (Some people may even equate that to being part of a team like safety or part of the Loss Prevention Committee or ISS and so on. But I digress). LAs function as Leads or colloquially Lead Assistants to the PAs aka Process Assistants who in turn function similar to assistants to managers, particularly Area Managers as you stated. L5 managers can also be viewed as Sr (Area) Managers while L4 can be at times considered Jr. Managers. Both are officially known as Area Managers.

About L3 & below: people often confuse Level 3s as Tier 3s or Level 1s as Tier 1s and so forth interchangeably. 

Tiers (can also) describe your tenure within the company, despite your Level. 

For example, if you've been there for at least a year or a year ¬Ω, roughly speaking, that is ‚Äúthe next *tier* up‚Äù. A Level focuses more on your position within the company. Sometimes happenings within Amazon exceeds research. One has to be in the company or know knowledgeable Amazonians or (former/current/internal/external) customers to really understand the nuances. However, that doesn't necessarily apply to you since you're part of the culture.

More to the point, someone can be a Tier 3 being in the company for at least 2 years but still be at Level 1. Reasons vary but a common reason is that being Tier 3 with less responsibilities but more time within the company pays more than a Level 3 with more responsibilities with less time within the company. A con to that could be a slow progression to leadership roles for the Tier 1 associate vs the Level 3 associate. 

Also, if a Tier 3 (but still Lv. 1) decides after so many years to finally move up to a Level 3 position successfully, in many cases, their pay will be slightly reduced to start at that position's (L3's) pay rate instead of what they could make as a tenured Tier 3 employee. Communication around affected employees, indicated that there were a number of upset tenured Tier 3 associates who became Level 3 PAs but weren't previously aware of this.

For best results, put your bids in early for progression up the chain of command. And don't just only settle for the next step up. Go for several levels up instead to compensate, etc. Like Jalen Pappe in the comments. And he's only 19 too! Yet he misses -Tier 1- Level 1 for honorable or legitimate reasons, he's even more proud of his accomplishment of being a -Tier 3- Level 3.

Note: a Level 9 would be considered the Director level(s) or the _report to_ , from the GM, also known as Regional Managers in a more traditional sense. Additionally, there seem to be site locations where there are no Senior Ops Managers but only Operations Managers instead. That may or may not be the reasons for those site's GMs to be an L7 instead of an L8.
label: Positive

I've been with Amazon for about a year and a half now, I work at a Nonsort Reverse Logistics site, and I was told the same information regarding Teir 2. However, I spoke with my building Site Leader of HR, and she informed me there are actually roles that fall under Teir 2. These roles include ambassador, problem solve, audit, IOL, and ISS. Teir 2 indirect roles are for associates who are wanting to advance from Teir 1 to Teir 3, or if they just want to advance their skill set. Teir 3 can also include Learning Trainer, Human Resources Associate, Safety, Hazmat, etc.; I hope this information was helpful!

comment:
Tired of the "automation won't replace humans, but work with them" nonsense. Entry-level today, mid/late career tomorrow, C-suite the next day. Starting with the great decoupling in the 1970s, human labor has been and will continue trending to zero. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY. Automation and robotics will necessarily replace human workers due to the current economic system. Today, AI is the WORST it will ever be going forward. It DOESN'T MATTER if AI "creates" 200 million new jobs...AI will solve and execute these new "jobs" much faster than humans will be able to adapt, learn, and fill them. Capital/employee model-it worked great...for quite a while. However, now companies that automate lower their costs, become more competitive. Those that keep higher-cost human labor necessarily fall behind and will go out of business. This creates a system where replacing people with machines is not just likely, but necessary for company survival. There is a way to deal with this humanely, but it would require a full revamp of the social contract and our concept of work. Even capitalists will want this change when unemployment reaches a tipping point and there‚Äôs no one left with money to buy the crap they‚Äôre selling.

I know, LLMs are leveling off, "what about the energy?," blah, blah, blah. Do not conflate LLMs with AI. LLMs are no more AI than vacuum tubes are computers or AOL dial-up is the internet. So, LLMs are leveling off. History shows technological advance is not just one sigmoid curve. It's a series of sigmoid curves with each successive one reaching new capabilities and new heights. To think that after 200,000 years, this pattern is all the sudden going to stop is absurd. I also understand there will be new jobs for humans created, it will go in this pattern: Automation creates 5 new jobs this year, lays off 30; creates 5 new jobs next year, lays off 500; creates 5 new jobs the following year, lays off 1500 etc. In the macro economic picture, do you not see this as an issue? I also understand there is more opportunity for entrepreneurs. Again, from the macro perspective there is a MINORITY of people that have the entrepreneurial ability/spirit. It takes that, and a strong majority of people don't have it.

Reasoning AI Is the Next Big Leap. The future of AI is not just about generating answers, but about ‚Äúreasoning‚Äù breaking down complex problems step-by-step, more like a human brain. Breakthroughs like DeepSeek‚Äôs open-source reasoning models are already being incorporated into platforms like GPT and xAI, marking a shift toward more advanced, thoughtful AI. Think EXPONENTIALLY, not LINEARLY.

There‚Äôs a persistent and misleading narrative circulating often perpetuated by short term goal-driven institutions like politicians, universities, and tech company executives, that the future of work is secure. The claim goes: ‚ÄúYou just need to learn how to work with AI,‚Äù and humans collaborating with AI will outperform either one alone. But recent research, including a landmark study from the University of Virginia, tells a different story. In diagnosing medical conditions, AI alone achieved far greater accuracy than either human doctors or even doctors assisted by AI. The median diagnostic accuracy for the docs using Chat GPT Plus was 76.3%, while the results for the physicians using conventional approaches was 73.7%. Sounds like ‚Äúa win‚Äù at first. However, Chat GPT Plus alone achieved a median diagnostic accuracy of more than 92%. In other words, the comforting idea that humans will always be essential partners to machines is crumbling. In many fields, AI is not just a tool, it is the superior performer. This has staggering implications for the future of work, especially to the often used solution of prior technological displacement that go ‚ÄúYou just need to be retrained.‚Äù To the group advocating the "retraining solution," I pose to you this: You have a medical doctor, just finished 8 years of higher education, a low-paid 4-year internship/residency, is hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt, and just got outperformed by automation; what would you have this doctor retrained into that will offer a secure job?

The result of this, since the United States' moronic system is based on taxing employees for about 70% of all tax revenue, this will further exacerbate the problem. Tax needs to be based on what's going on now and in the future not what worked 75 years ago. Oh I know it's so evil to think, but we might need to tax the companies who are doing the automation. Even if you do that, it's a win-win. For instance say a company had 1,000 employees in automated away down to 100. 1,000 employees paid federal taxes, including payroll tax, of about 20 million a year. Now the 100 people pay about 2 million a year. However, by automating, the company sees two things: they are no longer paying approximately 60 million in wages and their share of payroll tax, AND since nobody automates to lose money they also have higher profits. What's so wrong about taxing that company for the $60 million dollars they don't have to pay anymore and a fair percentage of their additional profits they now make through the automation. Not all the additional profits, but some of them. If you do that there's a higher tax revenue and more profits for the company. That's a win-win for the government and for businesses. If humanity, as a whole, weren't so stupid, we would just adjust as tech progresses to where EVERYONE benefits somewhat from each stage and just move smoothly into the post-labor economy.

To understand this shift, consider the historical role of the horse and oxen. They were once essential to the economy as sources of power for agriculture, transport, and industry. Technologies like the horse collar and the steel plow dramatically increased their output, making them even more valuable. But then came the steam engine and, later, the internal combustion engine. These machines didn‚Äôt just help the horse, but outperformed it entirely. Trains, tractors, and trucks could do the job ten, even a hundred times faster and more powerfully. And from that moment forward, the horse was no longer critical to economic output. It was, in essence, unemployed.

This is what AI and robotics are doing to human labor. They are not simply replacing the repetitive or the physical; they are increasingly outperforming humans in cognition, strategy, design, and communication. And just like the horse, our value in the economic system will diminish, not from lack of talent or effort, but because machines will do the job better. That‚Äôs why we need to start thinking not in terms of retraining, but about restructuring society itself for a world where human labor is no longer essential to production. When the very essence of what makes an entity useful to the current economy is superseded (be that strength, endurance, dexterity, analysis, creativity, empathy, intelligence, persuasion as well as many other qualities) that entity becomes irrelevant to economic output.

Potential solution. Decentralized AI Ownership: A Bridge Toward Post-Scarcity. While Universal Basic Income (UBI) may serve as an initial economic stopgap, bridging today‚Äôs economy with tomorrow‚Äôs abundance consider an even more equitable and long-term solution: Decentralizing the ownership of artificial intelligence itself. 

Rather than concentrating the power of AI in the hands of a few corporations or governments, envision a model where AI entities are open-source and collectively owned. This could take the form of assigning each person a digital "share" of an AI system, not unlike a stakeholder‚Äôs share in a company. As the AI produces value, whether through intellectual labor, creative output, or autonomous economic participation, those shares would generate dividends distributed directly to individuals. 

This model would ensure that as AI becomes the dominant productive force in society, the wealth it creates is shared universally, not monopolized. It aligns with the principle that the fruits of public knowledge made possible by centuries of human collaboration should benefit everyone, not just a few early adopters or private entities. In practice, this could look like: 

- AI systems running Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) that distribute profits algorithmically.
- Smart contracts ensuring transparent, equitable income flows based on collective stake.
- Global ‚ÄúAI cooperatives‚Äù where users vote on how AI is used, improved, and deployed.
- Universal basic compute.
 
If AI becomes the primary driver of economic output, then equitable access to its benefits isn‚Äôt just fair, it‚Äôs necessary to avoid deepening inequality and instability. It provides a scalable, technologically aligned extension to UBI, ensuring people not only have income, but true economic participation in the age of intelligent machines. 

Ultimately, decentralized AI ownership may be the last transition phase before full post-scarcity, when advanced technologies like universal nanofactories or matter compilers render even economic structures obsolete. Until then, however, models like this offer a way to reclaim agency in a world where production no longer requires human hands, and where wealth can, for the first time in history, truly be universal.
label: Positive

comment: I worked in the wafer mfg industry in the 80‚Äôs and 90‚Äôs. Seen the boom and suffered during the bust. After the threat of layoffs, greedy owners I realize I couldn‚Äôt go on. So instead of being laid off. I hunkered down and started a mobile welding business which got me a lot of work in other industries mainly food plants and those were abundant here in my home area. In later learned a shop with equipment was for sale due to bankruptcy and went to have a peek. It was only two blocks from my house. It was a decent shop very well equipped machine shop so I went home and counted my Pennie‚Äôs. I made an offer and it was accepted. I pulled a second on my house and was in business. My family thought I was nuts. I along with my teenage nephews cleaned up the place and made it presentable. I went to some of my food plant customers and looked for work. Lo and behold I became overwhelmed running a one man shop welding by day and night and machining parts ect. 32  years later business is good, I have eight loyal emplyees.  The shop building and land is owned by me and I‚Äôm semi retired. I took a big risky step and paid off.
