comment:
I‚Äôve been thinking a lot lately about how work just keeps getting harder with no real solutions in sight. These so-called 'mental health check-ins' feel pretty useless if the work culture doesn't change. I seriously wish someone would come up with a real solution to replace the whole KPI system. It's like everyone‚Äôs just obsessed with numbers, but it doesn‚Äôt actually make things better for people.

Here‚Äôs an idea: what if there was a global agreement that every employee should get at least 20 days of paid annual leave, excluding weekends and public holidays (like the Christmas shutdown in Western countries)? Some places could offer more if they wanted, but 20 days should be the bare minimum for everyone. Imagine if companies actually valued time off as part of a healthy work-life balance.

And speaking of work culture, why not encourage more 'mediocre' work? Not everything needs to be a race to the top. What if the target was simple‚Äîjust meet a minimum to get a guaranteed 2% pay rise each year? This could be something easy for most people to achieve, and if you wanted to go above and beyond, you could take on a higher target, but at least the basic expectations wouldn‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôre crushing everyone. It‚Äôd make work feel less stressful, and people wouldn‚Äôt be so scared to show up each day. Just a thought‚Ä¶ wouldn't that be a world with way less fear and burnout?
label: Positive

comment:
One of the most overlooked reasons great people leave their jobs is a lack of respect and the presence of discriminatory practices. Even when a job offers competitive compensation, growth opportunities, and a decent work-life balance, it cannot retain top talent if employees do not feel valued and respected.  

Disrespect in the workplace can take many forms, from dismissing employees‚Äô ideas and ignoring their contributions to failing to provide a safe and inclusive environment. Discriminatory practices whether overt or subtle create a toxic atmosphere that erodes trust and loyalty. When employees experience or witness bias, exclusion, or favoritism, it chips away at their commitment and morale.  

Top performers want to work where they are seen as equals, where their hard work is recognized fairly, and where they can contribute meaningfully without fear of discrimination. Organizations that fail to prioritize respect and inclusivity ultimately lose the very people who drive their success.  

For companies looking to retain great talent, it‚Äôs crucial to cultivate a culture of respect, fairness, and equity. This means actively addressing discrimination, listening to employees‚Äô voices, and fostering an environment where everyone feels safe and valued. Only then can organizations ensure they keep the best people who are not just working for a paycheck but are invested in the mission and values of their workplace.
label: Positive

comment:
This is the reason so many dedicated, passionate educators like me are leaving the teaching profession. It's not the money. It's the most horrendously top-down, creatively stifling, and toxic culture that is literally driving people to the point of breakdown. 
Teachers are generally self-motivated by the ability to influence and improve the lives of our students, we merely want our competency recognized and valued, yet we are forced to implement scripted curriculum and/or adhere to rigid curriculum pacing guidelines. We are asked to make lemonade out of lemons but given neither the time nor the resources to do so. There is no collaborative atmosphere, but rather adherence to the whims of a typically desk-bound dictator who assesses your performance based on observing  less than an hour of the thousands of hours you spend encouraging and educating, and bludgeons the people who aren't mollified by dress down Fridays and truly want to create something better.

comment:
The current company I am working for is perpetually in survival mode and MYSTIFIED about why they can't keep employees or find new ones. They had me join a group of employees to discuss how we could improve the culture and not even one day in and I got "well melennials don't want to work". I basically stopped the meeting and said, "Correct...we don't wan to work for you.". The meetings fizzled out as quickly as they started.

THEN my company wanted to conduct and employee survey. I got to personally go over the results with my company's leaders and the overall response was complaints about how "they couldn't give raises" or "should we just fire all of management?". After that meeting I left with this realization of there is absolutely no helping them. I'm not going to waste my own passion on a company that just wants affirmation in the things it does poorly.

comment: If I discovered this video when it was published I probably would've left as soon as my org started moving into survival mode (which isn't necessary since the company is doing well).  I understood why the new leadership was driving hard for results, but the reality and poor planning/preparation created a 'yes, ma'am' environment that isn't sustainable (and embarrassing in many situations where it was clear people were pleasing rather than being authentic).  Once we had 5 higher-profile Sr. Directors/Directors/Managers announce their departure, I knew the writing was on the wall.  After six amazing years at a company I love, I walked away.  I know there's privilege in doing so with an economy just starting to recover and still uncertainty for the future with variants, but like many others, it's time to take a break and reflect, and take action on figuring out what's next since tomorrow isn't guaranteed.  Agree with so many points of Ms. Lindor's talk -- well-explained and thought-provoking!

comment:
I quit today, on my 5th day. Standing more or less in one spot bent over totes for 10 hours was hell on my back and neck. The safety shoes are so uncomfortable, I just wore some black non-slip sneakers and nobody noticed. At my station in pick, you can't take a bathroom break unless the machines are being worked on or somebody covers you. The rate (after 5 weeks once you get used to it) is something nearly impossible like over 300. I didn't really get higher than 280 going at a pretty quick pace. The main parking lot is so small that I had to park way out in the bigger parking lot so walking in and out is a like 5 minute process. And I would work on the 4th or 5th floor so that means either stairs or wait for the elevator which seems to take forever.
 
The only good things are the pay and the ability to wear comfortable clothing including shorts and t-shirts, and hats. And the instant hire process. Seasonal employees don't even get benefits til after 90 days. The stupid robot machines would keep messing up for me, either getting stuck or not moving the totes. The last straw for me after already starting the day off on a bad note was the totes getting stuck and not moving. I walked out. I feel so guilty about it and really need the job and the money but I don't think I am going back tomorrow.
* I actually worked at Amazon from 2019 to 2021 and didn't like packing but did end up almost liking the dock. We got to load and unload trucks; it was active work and the time seemed to go by fast.
label: Positive

comment:
I worked at an Amazon warehouse for over 5 years. It helped me get credit cards and build up my credit score, get my own apartment, buy a car, pay off tens of thousands of dollars of credit card debt. Then I felt like I was a failure bc I had a degree and my family looked down at me for being a warehouse worker. One day I just quit my job at Amazon bc I would start literally crying at the thought of going to work. I only had $5000 saved up. I took out a loan of $27,000 to attend a coding bootcamp (it was called Codesmith = cost of tuition =about $20k and $7k for living expenses). 

They told us if we did exactly as they told us and followed all their instructions, it would take us 3 to 6 months to get a job. 

I did NOT follow their instructions and it ended up taking me 2.5 years to get a job. I went into an embarrassing amount of credit card debt. I finally got a job in the tech sector paying $10 an hour but I leveraged that job to get a better job after 6 months as a software engineer and then got promoted to senior software engineer within 3 months of joining the company (I worked my a$$ off - working 12 hours a day which honestly I was used to from my time at Amazon warehouses and working unpaid overtime all to impress my boss and it worked and I got the promotion).  



However 3 years since I quit my job from an Amazon warehouse I am working as a senior software engineer at a respectable company. 

However bc of the debt I accrued after quitting my warehouse job amazon as a fulfillment associate, I am honestly in a worse financial position even though I make 6 figures now since almost most of my salary goes back to paying my insanely high debts and loans. 

So idk how to feel - my days are a thousand times more stressful but maybe my self respect is higher but now I realize my time working at Amazon as a fulfillment associate was not as bad I thought it was. There can be worse ways to live your life. So yeah - maybe in a year my mind will change but that‚Äôs life - you gotta learn to pivot when things aren‚Äôt jiving with your heart and soul even if your mind says and thinks the opposite.
label: Positive

comment: All warehouse jobs sucks, I know. Keep your peace and sanity.

comment: That warehouse job was hell plain and simple. I did a month of 10-hour night shifts at Amazon, standing the entire time with barely any breaks. They didn‚Äôt even have shoes in my size, so I was forced to wear the wrong ones, and when I got home, my socks were bloody. The work is nonstop, the pressure‚Äôs insane, and you‚Äôre treated like a machine. Managers talk down to you, and I even got written up for spending 5‚Äì7 minutes in the toilet - no joke, I was actually using it. No one‚Äôs there by choice; they‚Äôre just stuck with no better options. I went and got my CDL right after I quit, and I haven‚Äôt looked back since.
label: Negative

comment:
i quit my auto parts warehouse job yesterday - posted this to Facebook

So i have been preparing to quit my Job and move on to other things for a long time. Just never made the jump. I been doing the work of at least 2-3 people for a couple years now after corporate bought our local business, cut half the staff in half and made the remaining people there responsible for 2-3 times the work. This seems to be the corporate mentality these days.  My feet have been hurting for over a year now, I was always trying different shoes. Asking to work less, or maybe they should hire 1 more person to help. I had to pick up hundreds of hundreds of car and boat batteries every week,  every day sometimes over 100 batteries in a day.  The last week or 2 my right foot was turning purple and blue and I had to go to urgent care.  Nothing was broken but I had a swollen vein and couldn't work anymore.  I was off for 5 days and they wanted me to come back but I still couldn't put pressure on my foot even though it is healing with treatment and rest. I've been preparing to leave this job for a long time, I have money saved, im good, I've been there 6 years.  I am 100 percent ready to start my new  journey. Just gonna rest and get 100 percent again  before I do. Im letting yall in on this personal stuff in my life becuase this is a decision I was not strong enough to just make on my own, switching jobs like this, but sometimes God makes the decision for you. And puts you in a position with no other choice. I truly believe God has put me through this to get me to move on and make a change in my life I've been too scared to make myself. And thats what im doing. My boss of 6 years, not the corporate manager, is also out with sepsis. Almost died. He is 65 and was being overworked like me, always telling me he was gonna quit and move to the mountains. I didn't find this out till I gave my resignation. And he might be done for good there too. Him and I were very close and he showed me what it's like to work hard and take care of ya family and ill never forget that. So by the Grace of God my last day and his last day were the same. Keep him in your prayers yall and if at least one of yall prays for him this morning that would be üíØ 
Again im only sharing this post to share the Grace of God. Love ya guys ü´∂ü´Çüôè
1 Corinthians 15 1-4

comment: I think it just comes right down to, if you don't mind being a robot then you are good. Our fulfillment center is chill asf. Rates? No problem, they seemed impossible at first, but once your body is on automatic mode you can literally chill and you are at or above rate. Bathroom breaks? Yea it depends on what position you are working that period, but usually a manager or neighbor will cover you. On other positions, we can go without saying a word, and not get a word spoken to us for it. Unless you take a 30-45 minute break of course. Also, it really comes down to the type of person you are, I see A LOT of lazy people in there that I know will be gone by the time seasonal is up, or sooner. Then they'll be right back. But if you just do what you are suppose to, which is work, then everything will be good. Very repetitive, which sometimes gets to me as well. But sometimes I like seeing how high I can get my rate and that makes the time go by faster. It really isn't that bad, it's just not for everybody.

comment:
These kinds of interviews are so ridiculous.  It's amazing anyone gets a job.  I got asked one time--tell me about a time where you gave someone the wrong information.  What kind of stupid question is that?  Why would I give someone the wrong information?  I just keep researching until I find the right information or give them the best information available at the time and am extremely clear that this is all the information that is currently available.  

Unless people are just out there making stuff up, no one can ever check your answer for it being the truth, so I guess just having a made up story rehearsed is probably the best way to get through the scam interview process.

comment:
"Tell me about" ... ?
Does anyone pay attention to the following impact:
1. An event 
2. A pattern (mastery)
3. An underlying structure (culture)
4. A vision (leadership)
5. A mindset (research logic, thinking skills: system, critical, lateral, disruptive, question, inversion, scenarios/evolution, etc)
6. Spiritual experience (something extraordinary/divine) happened.

Instead of STAR try (I)SBAR (Ask the interviewer, too):
I-Issue/Challenge
S-Situation, facts only
B-Background/Context
A-Assessment
R-Recommendation
Execution is another matter. 

Results in STAR should be further probed with R.O.I.:
R-Immediate "R"esult
O-"O"utcome, what change had to be made to support "R"
I-Long term "I"mpact

For example, two technicians plus an engineer resigned. After a "small" change I made, for the next two years (until the end of my employment),  the company never employed those three roles. Was it a small change? If I did nothing else, until I left, the change covered the cost of all my salaries and much more?  

In your interview, ask Amazon: How have you got rid of "I am right you are wrong" paradigm? (How) Do you practice Lateral/Disruptive Thinking? What have you learned?
label: Negative

comment:
Amazon leadership principles and sample questions: 
1- Customer obsession: tell me about a time you had a deal with a difficult customer. Or describe a situation where you negotiated win win 
2- Ownership: Tell me about a tough situation during your project or tell me a tough situation you made during a project event
3- Invent and simplify: tell me about a time when you solved a complex  problem and how you went about doing it? Or How you handle roadblocks or obstacles?
4- Right a lot -Strong judgment and good instincts: tell me about A time you had to make a decision without much customer data or with a lack of data  or tell me about a time when you had to convince team members on something that you proposed
5- Learn and be curious: tell me about a time you build out a process  or tell me about a skill that you recently learned
6- Hire and develop the best: tell me about a time when you had a conflict with some one. How did you resolve in it, what did you learn or tell me about a time when you fired someone? 
7- Insist on the highest standards: A time you had to make a decision to make short term sacrifices for long term gains or tell me about a time when you made a decision based on data and you were ultimately wrong
8- Think Big: Your greatest success? Or tell me about a time when you were creative?
9- Bias for action: How have you convinced others to take action? How have you managed risk in a project?
10- Frugality: tell me about a time you turned down more resources to complete a process or tell me about a time you had to accomplish big results with very little budget
11- Earn trust: An example of how you managed a conflict  or How do you earn the trust of your team members?
12- Dive deep: : tell me about a time the most complex project you worked on? Have you changed an opinion or direction using data
13- Have a backbone, disagree, commit: : tell me about a time you had a disagreement with your manager? Or How do you manage difficult conversations?
14- Deliver results: Describe a challenging product you worked on why it is challenging. Or How do you prioritize  
15- Strive to be Earth's best employer: : tell me about a time you had to motivate a team after a demonizing event?  :tell me about a time when employee gave you a negative feedback
16- Responsibility: : tell me about a time you had a problem and how to discover a real cause? Or Describe a time when your project failed
label: Positive

comment:
### Customer Obsession
- Tell me about a time when you had a deal with a very difficult customer.
- Describe a situation where you negotiated a win-win.

### Ownership
- Describe a tough situation in which you had to step into a leadership role.
- Tell me about a tough decision you made during a project.

### Invent and Simplify
- Tell me about a time when you solved a complex problem and how you went about doing it.
- How do you handle roadblocks or obstacles?

### Leaders are Right, A Lot
- Tell me about a time when you had to make a decision without much customer data.
- Tell me about a time when you had to convince team members on something that you proposed.

### Learn and Be Curious
- Tell me about a time when you built out a process.
- Tell me about a skill that you recently learned.

### Hire and Develop the Best
- Tell me about a time when you had a conflict with someone. How did you resolve it and what did you learn?
- Tell me about a time when you fired someone.

### Insist on the Highest Standards
- Tell me about a time when you had to make a decision to make short-term sacrifices for long-term gains.
- Tell me about a time when you made a decision based on data and you were ultimately wrong.

### Think Big
- Tell me about your greatest success.
- Tell me about a time when you were creative.

### Bias for Action
- How have you convinced others to take action?
- How have you managed risk in a project?

### Frugality
- Tell me about a time when you turned down more resources to complete a project.
- Tell me about a time when you had to accomplish big results with very little budget.

### Earn Trust
- Can you give me an example of how you managed conflict?
- How do you earn the trust of your team members?

### Dive Deep
- Tell me about the most complex project you've worked on.
- Have you changed an opinion or direction using data?

### Have Backbone; Disagree and Commit
- Tell me about a time when you had a disagreement with your manager.
- How do you manage difficult conversations?

### Deliver Results
- Describe a challenging project you worked on and why it was challenging.
- How do you prioritize?

### Strive to be Earth‚Äôs Best Employer
- Tell me about a time when you had to motivate a team after a demoralizing event.
- Tell me about a time when an employee gave you negative feedback.

### Success and Scale Bring Broad Responsibility
- Tell me about a time you had a problem and how you discovered the real cause.
- Describe a time when your project failed.
label: Positive

comment: The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 is a United States labor law requiring covered employers to provide employees with job-protected, unpaid leave for qualified medical and family reasons. The FMLA was a major part of President Bill Clinton's first-term domestic agenda, and he signed it into law on February 5, 1993. The FMLA is administered by the Wage and Hour Division of the United States Department of Labor. The FMLA allows eligible employees to take up to 12 work weeks of unpaid leave during any 12-month period to care for a new child, care for a seriously ill family member, or recover from a serious illness. The FMLA covers both public- and private-sector employees, but certain categories of employees, including elected officials and highly compensated employees, are excluded or face certain limitations.

comment:
What I dislike about these types of videos is they focus on one or two major companies. They don't show how this happens at many companies across the US. 

People make decisions around going home and losing their jobs vs continuing to work while not feeling well all the time. That's what it's like to be an hourly worker in the US. 

It's sad that people die due to this, but it's not just Amazon. Walmart, Sam's Club, BJs, TJMaxx, manufacturing companies, warehouse companies, etc have these same issues where someone can get let go for leaving work sick without having UPTO time. Some even keep a score of how many times you were out unscheduled and if you reach a certain score you get fired, no matter if you have a doctor's note.

Let's stop attacking one or two of the companies and start broadcasting all the companies that do this.

comment:
Many people that have worked as amazon drivers have quit, and it's understandable why so many amazon drivers quit.  Lots of amazon delivery drivers that quit are hard workers, have a great work ethic, are great employees, etc.

Many amazon delivery drivers quit since they constantly feel pressured and rushed to make 200 stops per day and make 20 stops per hour.  At Amazon, many drivers have to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour, and they're being monitored to make sure they're making 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.  There's lots of circumstances that occur that make it hard or even impossible to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour such as traffic jams, detours, rainy conditions, delivering several packages to apartment complexes, customers asking questions about packages, etc.  Many amazon delivery drivers urinate in cups on the side of the road due to fearing that if they stop somewhere to use the bathroom, they won't be able to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.  Many amazon delivery drivers skip their breaks, run stop signs, run red lights, etc due to feeling rushed and pressured to make 200 stops per day and 20 stops per hour.

comment:
i do my best not to order anything these days. stock up at the grocery store and never go inside the gas stations or dollar stores or fast food places even drive thru just to take the work load off the people who work there. posted this to facebook today

So i have been preparing to quit my Job and move on to other things for a long time. Just never made the jump. I been doing the work of at least 2-3 people for a couple years now after corporate bought our local business, cut half the staff in half and made the remaining people there responsible for 2-3 times the work. This seems to be the corporate mentality these days.  My feet have been hurting for over a year now, I was always trying different shoes. Asking to work less, or maybe they should hire 1 more person to help. I had to pick up hundreds of hundreds of car and boat batteries every week,  every day sometimes over 100 batteries in a day.  The last week or 2 my right foot was turning purple and blue and I had to go to urgent care.  Nothing was broken but I had a swollen vein and couldn't work anymore.  I was off for 5 days and they wanted me to come back but I still couldn't put pressure on my foot even though it is healing with treatment and rest. I've been preparing to leave this job for a long time, I have money saved, im good, I've been there 6 years.  I am 100 percent ready to start my new  journey. Just gonna rest and get 100 percent again  before I do. Im letting yall in on this personal stuff in my life becuase this is a decision I was not strong enough to just make on my own, switching jobs like this, but sometimes God makes the decision for you. And puts you in a position with no other choice. I truly believe God has put me through this to get me to move on and make a change in my life I've been too scared to make myself. And thats what im doing. My boss of 6 years, not the corporate manager, is also out with sepsis. Almost died. He is 65 and was being overworked like me, always telling me he was gonna quit and move to the mountains. I didn't find this out till I gave my resignation. And he might be done for good there too. Him and I were very close and he showed me what it's like to work hard and take care of ya family and ill never forget that. So by the Grace of God my last day and his last day were the same. Keep him in your prayers yall and if at least one of yall prays for him this morning that would be üíØ 
Again im only sharing this post to share the Grace of God. Love ya guys ü´∂ü´Çüôè
1 Corinthians 15 1-4

Managers would make huge deals and hyper inflate any tiny mistake I ever made (or even told me off for things I didn‚Äôt even do!), while completely ignoring huge problems that the toxic coworkers were causing with all their bullying. It was ridiculously frustrating how the rude people were treated the best, while the nice people like myself were treated the worst and walked all over! comment: Worked in a team that didn't believe I deserved the promotion as I was newer than others. They resented my hard work and great work ethnics as it made them look bad. They resented my manager seeing through that and accused him of favouritism towards me. So they all acted up and made my role as team leader impossible. They did not listen to any directions, instead challenged everything I said and criticised everything I wrote no matter how small or even if the same wording was used by a a general manager. As the words that came from me  became unacceptable. They made out that I was the problem, not them and their unwillingness to work or do their job. Eventually they left one by one until I had enough of the toxicity and couldn't handle it affecting my personal life. When I did leave after 2.5 years, the mastermind was taking work cover as working with me caused her too much stress. Working in the same building or having me say her name in a meeting or receiving an email from me induced an anxiety attack. This was all a scheme and drama that she created to get paid doing nothing from home for a year. When she finally came back she refused to join the team in the same building saying it was too stressful for her yet she complained about not being able to connect with the team. HR finally caught onto her fabrication and through many more months was able to get rid of her. What a waste if everyone's time and the company's resources. Dealing with entitled and lazy people at work who want to take the credit and happy to criticise anyone else who performs better is shameful and disgusting

comment: My comment disappeared- here it is again: all lower case since everyone is sensitive to Upper Case letters. Corporate Alert üö® Human Resources in any type of company is not humane. It should be called Corporate Services and they are there for the company‚Äôs best interests at all costs. Do not be fooled into thinking that Human Resources is a resource for the employees- it is solely for the employer. Trust no one but yourself, truly. Your coworkers are not really your friends they are your coworkers and that is it. It‚Äôs all survival in the workplace and those very same coworkers will try to find an edge over you and find your weaknesses and then exploit your weaknesses and will spread rumours about you which ultimately will ruin your livelihood and then you have no job. Be aware Be Careful Be Diligent with protecting yourself in the workplace. I worked for the municipal level government in my province for 20 years of my life. 2017 I was fired. Was it all my fault, no. Could I have done things differently‚Ä¶.üíØ but I got ‚Äúgot‚Äù and it was too late. ‚è∞ BUT Please don‚Äôt let others tell you what you are capable of doing and not doing. comment: I worked at this place a few years ago. The place was very cliquey. I wanted to move up after earning my degree. They did not just overlook me for an internal position I applied to, they gave me a write-up of things they had to actively find to defame me. I applied to another internal position. The unqualified HR girl with no degree came by my desk, and she said I could not apply to any position for 6 months, because I had a write-up recently. I looked at the employee handbook, and I could not find anything supporting what she said. However, they gave the position to the new person who had only been there for less than a month. The employee handbook does say that employees have to wait 6 months before transfering to a new position. They just pick and choose, or make up rules when they need them. I felt as they were stopping me from soaring by clipping my wings. That day, I noticed how narcissistic people can be and developed cynicism. I took the first job that came; however, it was an even worse job. A series of events happened at that job, and I left it too. Today, I work at a healthy workplace. I am still recovering mentally from those past jobs. There needs to be more awareness of narcissist at the workplace, and actual help with them. I should not have to deal with antagonists who like to step over people, because of some sort of trauma they've yet to overcome.

comment: A toxic work environment equals out to exactly the same as mental and emotional abuse. Why is this acceptable in so many places??? This is what I'm dealing with right now. My supervisor and co-workers make me feel like I'm the one with the problem. Yeah, I have a problem with certain people being able to have the freedom to have their choice of what job they want to do or not do, or even if they wanna do anything at all and just sit around and stare at the wall all day while I'm the only one doing any work and getting the shit end of the stick of everything. It's abuse. And if you don't click with them, they will abuse you as much as they can. It's sick that supervisors and other people are allowed to get away with this behavior. Back in the 90s it was worse and people expected you to keep your mouth shut and deal with it. Well why should people keep their mouth shut and deal with it these days??? Abuse and bullying goes much further than childhood or school incidences. It's a form of bullying and abuse. And I have enough respect for myself to know I don't deserve to be treated that way.

comment:
I'm in a toxic work environment right now. I deal with it by constantly asking for clarity, especially when I'm being lied to. I use the socratic method of repeating back the previous statement to see if my boss will repeat it or change the subject, she always changes the subject, especially when she's lying. 

When I hear feedback supposedly from others about something I said or did, I ask the who, what, where, when questions and say that I want to clarify what I'm being told wasn't taken out of context. Guess what? My boss deflects and tries to blame me or changes the subject. 

I send follow up emails or respond to emails after meetings and will copy my notes or respond to statements made by my boss that were untrue. I always cc HR in my correspondence with this individual. There now has to be a third party in our meetings due to her lying and trying to misrepresent what I say. Needless to say, these meetings have gotten much shorter, even though I'm the only one on the team who is being called into the office every Monday for a One-on-one and being micromanaged. I'm the newest member of the team and have been out pacing my counter-parts every month on numbers and growth for my market. I think my boss is afraid I could take her job, the thing is, I don't want her job, because I don't want to work directly with the CEO, she's worse.
label: Negative

comment:
People say, ‚Äúbe irreplaceable‚Äù. That‚Äôs silly. You will always be replaceable. My manager literally told me, ‚Äúanyone can be replaced like THAT‚Äù and snapped his fingers. 

I made all the mistakes. 
I gladly did everything I was told and happily embraced extra responsibility in order to prove that I was valuable. 

The expectations skyrocketed. 
The workload was impossible. 
It was also always ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù whenever the plate spinning trick failed. I couldn‚Äôt keep it going, but I set myself up for major burnout, simply by doing whatever I was told. 

Task upon task upon task was piled up on me. 

My work was then scrutinized. 

It got to the place where I was personally cleaning out and detailing my manager‚Äôs and his son‚Äôs cars. I was climbing up on the roof to repair shingles. I was doing everything that was beneath my manager to do. 

I would get an email from my manager saying he was tired of seeing a certain dandelion weed when he would walk from his car to the office. He told me to go out and pull it. 

I would get an email from my manager telling me that if I see the trash full I should empty it because this is a team. He even told me to push the bathroom trash down with  the toilet plunger to save on trash bags. Also he was personally unable to perform any of these tasks. It was beneath him. I was beneath him. 

I started valuing myself. 

He devalued me after that and discarded me.
label: Positive

comment:
My first job out of college flipped the script on me my first day working full time a few weeks ago. I worked part time at this office throughout the summer and part time at a restaurant. MY FIRST DAY being full time at the office they said "Hey we don't have enough resources to support the role you we're hired on for originally, could you do this completely unrelated role part time on Mondays and Tuesdays instead? It will be for no more than 6 months and we think you'll like it more!"   The wanted me to start this new role the following Monday. 


Um yeah, no.

 The owner came up to me and asked me so casually and I originally told them yes and they probably thought to themselves "What is she going to say, no? This is her only job now." The role they wanted me to do was the entire reason I pushed myself to go to and finish school; I had been in that role before in the past and I HATED IT. So, after a week of thinking things over and crying my eyes out about it to friends and family, I told my boss in writing that I could not accept the new role/position but that I will stay on for the role that I was originally hired for. We spoke about it in person the following day., I was very diplomatic, mature, and respectful about what I wanted to convey and why I had changed my mind. I just knew it wasn't the right role for me. 

While my boss was respectful and did listen to me, he also tried to make me feel guilty about not filling this role they desperately needed help with. He tried to belittle me by telling me I am not a team player for doing this to them and how another colleague who worked for them in the past and had the same education as me, did what this role for them when asked with no qualms. Well, good for her but I am not her and this is new position is not what I wanted at all. So, I politely told them if I was getting fired from my original role that I would grab my things from my room and leave, if not I would see them Wednesday morning. He didn't fire me and I didn't quit. I ended up getting a call the next day form him and after he spoke with his wife, (co-owner) about it they decided to let me go. All because I honored my feelings and stood up for myself.


I was praised for the work I did in my original role by patients at this office and by my other colleagues. I asked if I was being let go from that position, how did I underperform? They never scolded me for my performance and capability in my original role.  They didn't give me any feedback or response when I asked them how I underperformed in my role there. They we're just upset that I, like them, changed my mind.
label: Positive

comment: truth about the toxic environments here. i've been living this hell for years now.  i'd like to bail but hard to compete with benefits and pay out in the real world. i've become a monster. it's not something i like being but sometimes you  have to. i've taken out a couple problems above my paygrade. i'm also so knowledgeable on the roles i play, it would hurt to lose me. i'm through being pushed around, blamed, over burdened with unrelated tasks.  they told me to put in for a couple positions, told me to go get some schooling to solve some issues we are currently facing. i'm not doing the later for sure and i'm not getting promoted. they know it, i konw it, it's just a dance at this point. they, management, don't want a guy like me too close to them.  surviving is a matter of not giving them any ammo against ya, being in good standing with the right people to get things done and having they skillset they can't easily replace. a tip to those with bad management, let them fail. you don't have to go above and beyond. you don't have to set records. you don't have to solve the problems they pay others to solve. if that doesn't work, give them exactly what they ask for or both. they say to do something not critical to production, be on top of it at all costs to production. do the only the expected, nothing extra. kill the numbers enough times and they'll have to face the heat from above them. it's going to get rough but enough failures and they'll get got. maybe throw in a trip to hr with documented complaints on their reaction, go above their head to their boss if it'll help. key is being an asset to the company. i'm through being threatened and pushed around. it's a dangerous game though, too many hr complaints and they'll deem you the problem.  so make sure the heat you face is witnessed as much as possible. it may become a tool that you need.

comment:
I was a top performer for continuous 4 years and was the only person in the team that delivered work to the client in a 5-year project. My work got an award and recognized in the cooperation level (it was an international company). I liked what I did, and felt good and safe. I bought a house, 11 mins away from the company. 1 month after I bought the house, I was told the team was going to relocate to a different city, because the management was dreaming big about future (their future). I, as the main contributor has no choice but to relocate but others have the choice of working remotely. 
It was all of a sudden, and I had no preparation. I was so convinced about my performance and the job security until I realized everything can happen. Since that day, my attitude towards work completely changed. I no longer think in the position of the company or the team. I think of myself. I do things that help my own growth, finding excuses to not do things that irrelevant to my career goals. I care no more what the team wants to do, and prepare for any moment that the job is gone.
Did I relocate? Of course not. Did the management big dream come true? Of course not. The milestone was only half met with no client in the next two years. VP returned to his country, promoted the director that accomplished nothing before he left. All the money they spent contributed to our GDP growth, which was the only positive thing on this.
label: Positive

comment: This is an old video, but it just popped up on my feed after another one.  I have ADHD...I tend to speak my mind.  I was on a project a few years ago where they had a planned migration from .net Framework 4.5 to .net Core 8.  At the time Core 8 was a few weeks from final release.  The planned migration path was to upgrade in stages...I (think) Framework 4.7.2 was still in support and 4.5 had been out of support for 18 months.  The plan was 4.5...4.7.2...then...core....6....7....8.  Core 6 was in support longer than core 7; I said it was wrong to even consider core 7.  I also advised that they were wasting money by migrating to 4.7.2.  It might have still been in support but their website had been out of support for over 18 months...put you money and time into going straight to 8, and leave the live website as it is (out of support) for now.  I WAS TERMINATED!  The guy who suggested the upgrade path was (to the best of my knowledge) there for 2 years....and I don't think the upgrade ever got finished.  THAT is the reality of speaking your mind openly!
label: Positive

comment: My god, that description he gives at 9:30, OMG.. I was once hired at what was likely *the* best software company to work for in the province (for real).  I was hired as a general programmer to just kind of bang out whatever we needed and the very first project was a very ambitious "full stack" thing (BSD back end, windows client front end).  I knocked out a fully functional prototype within the first two weeks of working there.  Now, despite being small, they still did "big company" things for certain things like hardware procurement.  We hadn't set up *any* versioning, backups, etc yet and the entire windows side of that project was on my machine.  So, the boss is *super* happy and tries out a few binary builds of the app and things are great.  Life is good, the boss is happy, I'm happy, I feel fulfilled and then..  Then I accidentally shift-del the *entire* project directory tree.  Poof, gone.  The next 24 hours was *tooons* of fun.  Had to fenagle a second boot drive from the hardware/software procurement manager, then sift the damn filesystem for the source.  This story ends happily though.  I developed robust backup habits *and* I ended up working there for the next half decade!  Hurray!  But man, that 24 hour period of sifting for all the source and getting everything back in order... I nearly had a stroke. :P
label: Positive

comment:
Prime‚Äôs speech about pushing through in tough situation reminded me of my career before coding.
So I was a navigational cadet on merchant vessel when I was 18. My first voyage was a nightmare. My superiors didn‚Äôt like the way I worked and were harassing me(verbally), my colleagues didn‚Äôt like me much, because I didn‚Äôt drink with them(was not a fan of alcohol) and was a bit introverted(didn‚Äôt participate in talks, preferred to read). Overall, I felt quite bad, hated it, but decided, that I must be strong and keep on with this job. Ten years later, I left this job, still hating it, though being moderately successful. 
Now, I am working as web dev and enjoying every minute. And I really wish, i realized it much earlier. So yeah, sometimes it‚Äôs much better to leave the job you hate, and look for something you actually enjoy.
P.S. I did become more resilient and strong mentally and emotionally because of harsh conditions. But I don‚Äôt believe it was worth it, tbh.
label: Positive

comment:
0:14 "I refused to put food back in, that was served on tables"
That's really common actually. They also will pick up food that fell on the floor and put it back on the plate. I've seen a lot of things working in restaurants that are really gross. The worst of which are reusing napkins that customers leave behind, using them to drain oil from stuff coming out of the fryer. Or simply rinsing out a large tub full of raw chicken to be used the next day for chopped vegetables. Or cutting raw chicken on a cutting board then using that same cutting board for cutting vegetables or other food. Apparently cooking most of the food (i.e. stuff that was contaminated by raw chicken) is what keeps these businesses from getting bombed with bad reviews for food poisoning, but just the "idea" of what they're doing is extremely disgusting that I would never eat there.

comment: Dude!  I owned two pairs of OP shorts (I lived in Redondo Beach in the 80s and surf gear was the daily wear) and two Lighting Bolt shirts.  Those were hard earned I treated them so well.  I still have t-shirts that I bought when I got my first coding job in the 90s (a little threadbare, but still wearable).  One thing you learn is to take care of your shit.  100%  I grew up poor AF.  There were days when we had a single meal, and most of the stuff in our house was hand-me-downs from my mom's brothers.  Dad was nowhere and mom was too proud to take government assistance, so she worked two jobs to make ends meet.  She was a waitress and a bartender.  We lived on tips.  It's the reason why I always tip at least 15% and I have been known to tip 100% on some things.

comment: Ok I gotta rant a bit here. I was raised Catholic (wasn't molested), and hated it, abandoned it as quickly as I could.  But I'm a late life Christian myself only my gurus are scholars like Bart Ehrman who've read deeply into the scripture. To me scripture is literature, something to puzzle out. So that's why I own a Bible, read it occasionally and follow scholars a bit online. To me Jeebus was a Jewish preacher who preached the coming of God's Kingdom on earth IN HIS LIFETIME - love thy neighbor, repent and receive the good news. He may have been a bit grandiose and claimed to be the Messiah. In Luke he promised dominion over the 12 tribes of Israel to his disciples - twelve almost totally if not totally illiterate nobodies from Galillee. Did that make sense? In the three synoptic Gospels, he doesn't once claim to be God. Did he work miracles? Sure I guess. But so did other prophets. The apostle Paul is a whole 'nother story. I don't care what your religion is as long as you don't hurt nobody but it's all hooey to me (ever really try to read Revelation?), an outmoded way of dealing with reality. There are better ways only almost none of us are shown those ways hence falling into self medicating of various kinds.. All that said, thanks to P for sharing his story.

comment:
Eh, I disagree that "the more challenging a situation you go through, the better you will be at life". I suppose it depends on what you mean by "challenging", but I hear you saying that the more difficult a situation you go through, the better you will be (because you seem to be talking about Amazon's work culture).

There are definitely difficult situations that cause you to grow and become stronger and better. But there are also ones that do nothing but drain and weaken and damage you and leave you *less* able to prosper afterwards. 

For instance, a lot of people who go to war don't emerge from it "stronger" -- a lot of them emerge with terrible injuries or health issues and with psychological trauma that cripples their ability to function in civilian society.

I think it's important to recognize a distinction between a "challenging" situation, where it's difficult but there is the potential to overcome if you grow and become strong, and a "corrosive" or "toxic" situation, where no matter how good you become it will still suck and will only drag you down and diminish you. People should embrace challenging situations, but they should *not* tolerate corrosive or toxic situations. And in my experience most companies are more corrosive and toxic than challenging in this sense. Especially the ones that try to spin their toxicity as "hardcore" or whatever.

I think these things can be individual, however -- like, one person may experience a situation as toxic whereas another may experience it as challenging, depending on a bunch of factors. Hell, the same person may experience the same situation differently at different points in their life.

But if you are in a toxic situation, I don't think there is a benefit to staying there. I don't think it makes you stronger or better -- quite the opposite, in fact. If something is making you weaker, why would you do it (unless you've specifically resolved to make that sacrifice for family or something)? Definitely give it a minute before deciding....but if a job is stressful and leaves you feeling like shit every day and that doesn't change or at least start to subside in a reasonable time, don't continue at that job any longer than you absolutely have to. Because it does not serve society or individuals to condition people to endure abuse or look at employer abuse as "challenge".
label: Negative

I have a similar story:  I started working at this company called The Phoenix Group.   long story short, they dealt with credit/debit card terminals that you swipe your card to pay for things.   It was the first job outside of the Military that I consider to be a real job. I was good at what I did and I wanted to make it a career.   I was a Quality Control tech that just was good at what I did.

We got bought out by Ingram Micro, which is a Fortune 100 company.  I was pretty excited about it, I was thinking "these guys surely know what they are doing"  and then when they took over and got their teeth into the company they single handedly mismanaged it and ran it into the ground in less than 2 years...  When we we The Pheonix Group,  the company had been around for over 20 years...  when we were Ingram Micro: Secure Payment Solutions,  we lasted 2.

You can not tell me, that a Fortune 100 company is THIS incompetent at actually running a business.  there is no reality in which this makes the slightest amount of sense.

But apparently, that's just how these corporations are?   it's like, Come on, you could take an 18 year old working at McDonalds with 0 experience outside of customer service/retail and they could do a better job at running a company than these people running these multi million dollar corporations.

comment:
üó£Ô∏è Voice of the Associate (VOA) Post
‚ÄãSubject: System Barriers and Productivity Stress During Peak
‚ÄãIt is incredibly frustrating to experience ongoing productivity dips that are clearly caused by system or equipment failures, like the persistent scanner issues at sortside 24 C rebin. We, the associates, are held to increasingly intense rate standards, especially during high-pressure times like the run-up to Cyber Monday at facilities like FAT1. When our work is directly hindered by factors completely out of our control‚Äîa faulty scanner, a frozen wall, or slow induct flow in AFE1‚Äîit feels demoralizing and unfair. This situation forces associates to push harder to maintain an impossible rate, which only increases stress and can lead to burnout. We need reliable equipment and prompt maintenance to meet goals and ensure our productivity records accurately reflect our effort, not technical barriers. A smoother week, free of these systemic barriers, is essential as we enter the holiday peak.
‚ÄãThis video discusses common barcode scanning challenges, which relates to the scanner barriers you mentioned in your VOA.

comment: They have a thing called "scan to scan" when you go on paid break portion your last scanned item before break and first scan item after break has to be less or equal to your break time.  So a 30 minute break is not a real 30 minute break and these Amazon warehouses are the size of a school university like 5 story building so just walking to break room or to your car takes several minutes.  I got a ear full on my first day for having 5 MINUTES of TOT (time off tasks) and was told this is my first warning and if it happens again it may lead to termination...ON MY FIRST DAY!  They do allow 3 minutes grace of TOT but if you make it a habit they will have a talk with you too.  So on a 10 hour shift you get a 30 minute lunch and a 30 minute break that is actually really 18-20 minutes.
label: Positive

comment:
I worked at a toxic company for two months and left for a higher raise, a positive team that I actually like, and a shorter commute working for state government in NY. I absolutely despised the owner of my last company and was about to quit before they let me go after the owner screamed at me for over thirty minutes for a really minor mistake. Everyone there was absolutely miserable because the owner sucked the fun out of working there. Not a nice person at all. Never acknowledged me and only communicated through yelling. He yelled at other staff as well and had a very "my opinion is the only opinion that matters" personality. He was very rude, and never made the place of business a positive culture. Just always the mentality of "I pay your salary I am your god" which is gross and not a good leadership trait.

If I wasn't let go, I was already firing up my resume, hoping to get out. I am much happier in my new role, making more money and enjoying and getting along with my team now. If you are in a toxic space, leave. Even if you have to take a pay cut, if you can stomach it, leave for a better situation. Not worth you losing dignity getting screamed at like you are five or getting burned out
label: Positive

comment: I work at an Amazon Fulfillment Center. Just to let people know that not all of them have robots. Mine has none. When we pick it consists of hauling ass on multiple floors. We walk about 10 miles a day. Stowers get totes tossed on carts and they need to go and find locations where they can put the product on multiple floors. On top of that they make you cross train to be able to work other departments and the do not pay you extra for knowing other jobs. Holiday season or Prime days are fucking torturous. My facility 6 days a week 10 hours a day for weeks on end. People get hurt constantly and they don't give a fuck about you they only care about their number of products that is leaving the building. They don't have enough people they say fuck it and crank up the speed of the lines and work you till you are actually bleeding from smacking body parts of their totes, conveyor, carts etc.... all while coming to you giving you shit because shit isn't going out as fast as they would like. The product you order is stuffed with other random shit. You order a bag of skittles its jammed in a cardboard bin with motor oil and bleach cleaning products. Stuffed so much that often the cleaning products will break open and get all over everything else in the bin. Do they care.... nope! They keep idiot workers like me because they pay you a dollar more an hour than all the other business in the area. Work weekends.... sure, here's a shift differential. Mine 85 cents. You want a life outside of that place best of luck to you because you are healing and absolutely too tired to function on your days off.
label: Positive

comment: i do understand your position, it is not convenient running on other peoples or bodies schedules. Sometimes we just need a break. However, leadership principles outline expectations of the company. Amazon attains a lot of wealth, simply by outputting more than others. If you want a slice of that pie, you have to work. If you enjoy serving customers, and you find purpose in the work - its not bad. Economic opportunity is a big blessing, and we lose sight of this. SWE for amazon get many perks, such as working with bright and polite individuals, beautiful offices, healthcare, and of course amazing pay. I don't think 2 years is enough to make judgements about the ethical position of a company. Just because they like beef and you like chicken, doesn't make them evil. Metrics are key to success, without numbers, we cannot find truth. If everyone on your team is getting 10 points, and your getting 5, and your argument is that the work is meaningless, then thats not the companies fault, thats yours.

comment: Over the past 3 or so years, I have seen a few coworkers leave the company I'm at now for Amazon. The work is pretty boring, the pay is mediocre, but the work-life balance is almost unmatched for a software engineer. But they chose to jump ship, in spite of all of the well known problems at Amazon, either for the money or the career progression. I find myself asking the same questions. Is enduring the world of Big Tech worth the squeeze? With the mediocre salary I'm getting now, I simply can't afford to progress (buy property, go on regular vacations, etc.) in my HCOL area. But my self doubt is telling me, "Am I even capable of lasting more than a year without getting PIP'd?". Sounds like you did think it was worth the squeeze based on the money and prestige you gained. I'm looking at Amazon right now simply because I have evidence that I can make it past the interview process in the form of my coworkers who have the same experience. Maybe another question is, are there other Big Tech companies with a better culture that I'd have a shot at getting into or is Amazon known for being a little easier to get into than the rest of FAANG?

comment:
Current Amazon employee here (for the rest of January at least)
Hoping this reaches someone thinking of working for amazon or already works there and helps them out.

First of all this is a great video that puts the mental aspect of the job into perspective and i appreciate you put the time and effort into making and putting this out.

Second i been an on and off employee since about 2015-2016. 
Only reason i would keep going back is bc of how easy it is to get hired. I used to be a huge pothead and the mouth swab test was easy enough to pass with only a 1-3 day tolerance break.
Also for those that say theres never any openings, Amazon's turnover rate is stupid high + their positions are in high demand, probably because of reasons previously stated. Meaning multiple spots can be dropped AND snatched up within the same hour.. sometimes minute. Crazy to hear, but yeah I've checked their hiring page multiple times a day, saw literally nothing the first 20 times i checked, randomly see 10 spots in locations all around me the 21st check, and then refreshed the page and they would all be gone.
This is coming from someone thats worked at, at least 5-6 different amazon buildings. Either resigned, or terminated for going negative on hours. Nothing too serious.

Now im back at Amazon, started at an XL delivery station and met a friend that told me to apply for TOM team. Finally got in after a couple months of applying, started training, and worked for a couple months before they started preparing me for CDL school, 100% paid for.
Been on Tom team for a little over 2 yrs now and just put in my 2 weeks to go work for another company.

Anyways, all that to say any L1 position in amazon SUCKS
L3 PA too from what I've heard. 
But under the right mindset, can be one of your best stepping stones available. 
If you can tough it out long enough to get your benefits, or be blessed enough to work at a building that starts you out as a blue badge employee, please utilize career choice or start applying for TOM team if you don't hate the idea of driving tractor-trailers. TOM team is like a whole different section of amazon. Managers actually have your back and the teams are always close and helpful. The work is busy sometimes, but for the most part, management is understanding and willing to partner with you for anything youre going through.
That being said, i still see it as a stepping stone. Got my CDL, got my experience, and now going to make more money with a better schedule. Leaving with no hard feelings for once! I thank amazon this time and appreciate what its done for me.
I dont wanna sound like a simper by any means, but there's ways to work around the system developed by the higher ups and get outta there before you feel stuck!

Also i know I've said under the right mindset L1 positions can be an amazing stepping stone, but i do wanna say to avoid all delivery stations like the plague. They'll work you to the bone and then feed those bones to the yard dogs. 
FCs, SCs, etc are the way to go.

tldr CAREER CHOICE OR TOM TEAM ASAP
label: Positive

comment:
Do the math. 
4 days for 40+ hours/ week.  
That's 160 hours in 8 days vs. 10, so you're already winning there. 
Average pay 22.25/ hour, x1.5 OT. 
Reg pay: $178. OT pay: $66.75
Total daily pay: $244.75. 
Total weekly pay: $979
Total yearly pay: $50, 908.
Your taxes are subjective. 

But the point is, with 52 extra days off, plus great benefits, and very little human interaction, $50k/year is decent and definitely NOT a bad gig. 

Now, the best part is that you can add an extra $12k to your salary by simply adding an extra day, which is ALWAYS AVALIABLE. In which case $63k/year is solid in most areas. 

(6 days /week = $76k/year)

comment:
If they included the CDL drivers, the death toll would be staggering.  Source? Me, I'm an amazon cdl driver. Im teeeechnically not an amazon employee, im a "freight partner," a cheap and bs way amazon can not pay ANY benefits. , AND they can go, "oh that guy? Pfft hes not even an amazon employee. I drive an amazon decal'd semi truck. I am only allowed to pull 53 foot amazon trailers. We have those same monitoring cameras in our trucks but worse- they can, will, and do listen to your private conversations and u can get in trouble for em. Who do you think makes my schedule? Amazon. My MAX speed? 65. They give me 3.5hrs to get from say okc to downtown dallas, with a check in time at 530pm. Ohhh you gave me the same amount of time as it would take me in a CAR, that could ACTUALLY go the speed limit... and you want me to keep this literally impossible schedule AND expect me to do it at the worst time of day, in the most congested highway system, in the worst city in the entire south and Midwest states.. thats all? Ah, if its not possible, simply call this line in India, and tell them, and pray to THEIR god that they actually understood you and notated it correctly. If they didn't. Pfft bye. Hope u had apps out there already. Stopped to take a leak one single time? That call and note that would save u? Now voided, see, u stopped driving for like 4mins. 

How long do you think my day is? 14 hours. Every day. No matter what. Annnnd at the end of the night, when the 14hr FEDERALLY regulated clock runs out, and i LEGALLY cant drive? Oh, easy, simply clock out, and go find parking in downtown dallas at 2am at one of ohhh 5 truck stops in a 150 mile radius?  If u get caught by dot, thats on u, we told u to clock out. How they get away w that bs- india runs that department, they dont know our laws, and those that do, dont carez OR, they themselves are under desperate pressure to make a schedule that they know outright is physically impossible. But at least they got the loads out the door on paper. I could go on, and on, and on.

comment:
I can only speak for where I work. I work at a sortation center and it really isn't that bad. The work is easy and most associates are lazy, spending more than an hour of their shift talking or waiting for the bathroom to be available for their 4th trip to the bathroom on a 4 hour shift. No one gets fired for lack of productivity and most ppl avoid heavy lifting, so there's not much opportunity for injury.

Most injuries are the result of associate incompetence. Lifting the wrong way after being shown dozens of video demonstrations on how to lift safely. Pellets falling over because ppl don't make any attempt to stack boxes properly. 

I can say that they don't pay me and a handful of other workers enough, but that's because we actually work at work. A lot of ppl spend most of their time socializing and to be honest, they are getting paid more than they deserve. There is hardly anyone working at my location that I would ever consider hiring if I needed a hard working employee.

comment: I worked for AWS as SDE II for about 9 years and I can confirm every review in this video, it could damage you physically and mentally. I created lot of software and drivers, I fixed bugs of any kind for years. However, I was forced against my will to do oncall turns day and night for one week, sometimes 2 weeks in the same month where I got paged at 3 AM or I had to work at sev 2 tickets for the whole night. I lost lot of sleep. I was stressed in a period at the point that I developed idiopathic ventricular tachycardia and I was hospitalized in ICU for 8 days, I had to do coronary angiography and electrophysiological study. Fortunately my arrhythmia disappeared with betablockers and some weeks of rest. After that, I continued to work hard for the company like nothing happened. Never recognized for the efforts I've done so far, never received a promotion in years. I understand people who say it can touch you on a personal level. One day my manager told me that I couldn't get promoted because I'm not "popular". Now, I have to leave the company because of return to office (RTO). Do you know what? I'm happy with it. Now my health is much better and I will enjoy a better way to live. I suggest the same to everybody. Do not waste your time, talent and health on these big companies.
label: Positive

comment:

Titles get handed out like business cards
Incompetence gets protected if it‚Äôs well-connected
Merit exists on paper‚Ä¶ but influence runs the room
You‚Äôre expected to respect authority even when it‚Äôs obviously unearned
And then you end up doing the actual work while someone else takes the credit because their network is stronger than their skillset.

Democracy works ONLY IF you have a team of competent people willing to co-operate. It‚Äôs never the case. The teams are like a headless chicken running around in a semi- permanent panic. No wonder no work gets done if there is confusion, no clear scheme of delegation, no clear procedures, and no accountability! Add to that the office politics, and there you have it. Fucking frustrating waste of time and energy. Sometimes it is personal, most of the time it‚Äôs not. And they‚Äôre not even malicious. Just fucking stupid. And there is absolutely nothing I can do about it. Urgh üò§üòñüò≠

comment: I've worked in warehouses in the past and when I was in between jobs, last time was around 2016-2017. There were places that I looved and others that I hated, it all depends on what your supervisors and colleagues are like. Taking a leak is always an issue, I remember working in a warehouse where the supervisor had to scan his card to open a door that led to the toilets, and he was typically in a forklift 600ft away when you needed to go! Nevertheless, the warehouse jobs are pretty much stress-free. Granted, they can give you targets on how many pallets to sort and then manipulate your workload so that you have to walk half a mile to find the correct cage/box, but it's generally easy to pull through the shift.  The only stress I had was clocking in on time, and that was it. Office jobs are far more stressful.

comment: I worked at one for Amazon during my early 20s right after graduating college a few years ago. I knew it would take me a while to get a job out of my degree so i started working at the first job i got because i needed money asap. I worked at amazon for a little over a year. I was actually stuck there because i needed to work full time and had to help pay bills and my student loans which were a little under 6k. For a full year, i worked my ass off. Barely bought anything for myself after each paycheck. The job was bad on most days. But the pay was decent for a fresh graduate who was living with his family. I payed off my student loans and credit card debts in less than 6-7 months. Like i didnt even buy any new clothes when i got the job there becasue i focused on paying off my debts and helping out with bills. I also helped mh parents and siblings out with money whenever they needed. All i spent my money on for myself was on gas and food. After i payed off my debts, I saved up a month's worth of money and went on a shopping spree to reward myself. I worked full time for a few months longer and then switched to part time and got a job in accounting from my finance job. Anyone who feels stuck in a job they hate, you have to make some sacrifices for a while such as strictly saving up and then find something you like. Pleaze try to do something that will make you happy because life is just getting harder each day.
label: Positive

comment: This reminds me of when I retired 7 years ago. While I was visiting my sick Mother on the East Coast (she passed while I was there), my job (great pay & benefits with a Union) had offered a retirement package to 9 of us older clerical employees. I was working past my retirement age to help my Daughter put my Granddaughter through college. When I got back, my Supervisor called me into her office to tell me she was adding more work to my desk (hated what I was doing). Without hesitation, I told her I was retiring. I hadn't even told HR that I was accepting the package deal.  That was the best thing I could have done for myself. I'm glad I did because later I was diagnosed with cancer (doing good, so far). I admire your strength and courage to follow your heart and do what's best for you. Continued prayers for you in following your dreams.üôèüèΩüôèüèΩ‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§  Stay Blessed and safe!

comment: I am an SDM at Amazon for 4.5 years now with the same team and everyday I learn something new. The average time for engineers with me is about 3.5 years and the job satisfaction is quite good on the anonymous surveys. I think you got a bit of a bad luck with your team ownership and culture. It's not the same in every org. I do see allot of care and interest in having the engineers engaged, motivated and happy with what they do. Before I joined I did hear some stairs about people crying in their desk, but I have never seen that. We have team events every 2 weeks and an offsite every quarter sponsored by Amazon. But I see you took the right decision, being happy with what you do and have passion for that is what's going to make your time fly. I do agree the benefits are not great, maybe just average but nowhere compared to top companies, but the stock went 4x since I joined, so I can't complaint there. Thanks for sharing your experience

comment:
- **Amazon's relentless pursuit of perfection**:
  - Compared to Microsoft's earlier years, Amazon is **ruthless** in seeking perfection, focusing on driving constant improvement and achieving market dominance.
  - Amazon has **mastered the art of asking probing questions** and requires answers, pushing for concrete outcomes without allowing business processes to develop without direction.
- **High-pressure work environment**:
  - Working at Amazon is not considered a long-term career for most; **employees typically last around two years** due to the intense demands.
  - **Mistakes are not tolerated**, and repeated errors lead to quick exits, reinforcing a culture where high performance is mandatory.
- **Employee experiences**:
  - Many professionals, even those with long careers at companies like Microsoft, **burn out quickly at Amazon**, feeling exhausted and uninterested in future work after short tenures.
  - While **compensation is good**, the only recognition employees often receive is through pay, with little emphasis on praise or job satisfaction.
- **Contrast with Microsoft**:
  - Microsoft, in contrast, offers a more **relaxed and enjoyable work environment**, with recreational facilities like **foosball tables, gaming machines, and a cricket stadium**, promoting a balanced workplace culture.
  - This congenial atmosphere leads to a **sustainable and less exhausting experience**, differing significantly from Amazon's high-pressure approach.
label: Positive

comment:
Awful lot of cry babies in this line of work all wanting something for nothing. Why not just go to college and put in the academic work necessary to get an actual career? If you want a job, then don't bother doing anything after high school, or drop out of high school entirely. If you want a career, then stay in school and go on to an actual college or university after. I chose to major in science. Now I'm a full-time laboratory animal researcher that sees more money in one day by conducting phlebotomy and potentially life saving case studies involving animals compared to what anyone sees in a single week shuffeling boxes around. Not only that, but I actually enjoy what I do everyday for how rewarding it is.
But I see this issue coming up a lot with millennials and the so-called "gen xers" of our workforce. A lot of you just don't want to bother with the academic work to go any further in life for one reason: LAZINESS. And then you all get pissed off upon realizing the only types of jobs available to you are in brain-dead slave labor roles like warehousing. Well? What else do you expect?... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
If you enjoy warehouse work then all the power to you. I'm pointing people who end up in warehousing and just basically want to blame everybody else for being stuck at a job they hate. And yet you're the one that filled out the application. You're the one that went to the orientation (so you knew what you were getting yourself into). And you're the one that walks through the door to hit the time clock. Nobody else put you there. And after working for only a few months, you'll blame management for not treating you nice by giving you a pat on the back or the golden key to the crapper for what you do. You guys even go so far as to blame customers like me that use amazon pretty regularly. And that doesn't make very much sense at all. Why should the customer be put to blame because someone hates their job at amazon ? 
That's no different than going into a McDonald's and being treated like crap by the person at the cash register because they're unhappy with their "McJob." And all you did was ask for a coffee. Fair? (Not at all).
Remember, CUSTOMERS are the baseline for every business, and also the main reason why anyone serving in retail gets a paycheck in the first place. And that's better than nothing. Amazon workers need to do their job so I can do mine. My role relies on having readily available access to things like syringes, vials, microscope slides and pet food on a very consistent basis. If you don't like what you're doing then quit and enroll in some classes to get an actual career. You can walk right out the same door you walked in through at any time. You guys arn't prisoners...
label: Positive

comment: We created a monster with Amazon.  Well I am glad to say I have not used the site regardless of how crazy that may seem to most.  I remember when the small hardware stores in Philly were selling out before Home Depot or Walmart arrived and at a young age I understood the good and bad that was to come.  Personally I have no problem paying more for an item from a local business and I do not need everything in my hands yesterday.  We have all become addicts to convenience and it is all changing going into 2021.  Jeff Bezos (Not his initial last name) wants to control all retail aspects across the board to implement a system that will be based on a minute to minute supply/demand algorithm.  Parts for a 20 year old truck will no longer be affordable, trending will take on a whole new meaning, and worst of all he will eventually control thoughts and impulses should a neurolink become a mainstream item.  I give him credit as a businessman with unheard of drive but the story he tells does not hold water for me.  I believe he and most figureheads of big tech companies are in someway knowing or unknowingly acting on behalf of DARPA and/or a certain 3 letter agency to play the roll while being am innovator yet taking direction from handlers playing the world game of chess.  It's all about power and if you follow the money or better yet the data, you will find the wizard behind the curtain.  Mr. Bezo's "leaked" text messages to his girlfriend seemed more along the lines of amateur, even laughable and desperate for a guy worth $100's of Billions.  He most likely had to be put in his place and a honeytrap or simply a news headline picked up by the Sun or TMZ type of media falls in line with a 3 letter agency that literally goes about it's business with an unlimited budget and no oversight.  The new oil is data and since that agency acts as the global leading cartel, my money is on them controlling all we the people helped them create in record time.  Amazon is a blood sucking, soulless company that I can not see any one happily working for in general.  Two years would be like aging 10 years.  Look at their hiring and treatment in fulfillment centers and let's not even mention their trucks and drivers being hammered to the point they do not care about the vehicle or blocking a main street in a big city.  I wish you all the best in the future and hope we can all come together as a species otherwise we will tear each other apart in some way or another.  Maybe it's too late...All I know is that I will not take part in their reset and new normal...I do not fear the only guarantee in life after we are born.  There is much more energy and consciousness that my soul and all souls will experience after judging oneself following physical death...Gotta be truthful and real in the end.  Bezo's thinks of himself as a god that will live forever...Sounds more like a demon to me since we are living in hell on earth going into the year 2021 or whatever year it is or isn't.
label: Positive

comment:
I‚Äôve never worked at Amazon but I currently work for a company who used to be a vendor for Amazon and I used to be the person in charge of looking after purchase orders, ASN‚Äôs, and shipping discrepancies. We eventually had to pull out due to their insanely high expectations. They have very strict shipment windows that leave no wiggle room for back orders, they need every box to be packaged a certain way which takes more man hours than normal, they constantly try to dictate how you sell your products (pkg quantities), how much you sell your products for, and should you fail to meet their requirements at any of the above, you get charged an infraction fee. I was so relieved when my company decided to cut the cord. To them, most companies are just a drop in the bucket. It was a huge pain in the ass to cut ties with them too.
From a buyers standpoint, they‚Äôre great. Be careful when becoming a seller though. Things get tougher as the volume grows.
label: Negative
